00:22:35.943 --> 00:22:38.496
this episode, so signing off,
I am Peter VanRysdam.

442
00:22:38.496 --> 00:22:39.274
>> And I'm John Spence.

443
00:22:39.274 --> 00:22:39.949
>> And we'ill see you next time.

444
00:22:39.949 --> 00:22:49.853
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this session you will understand how to start the team off on the right foot, the importance of creating a team charter, tools for having more effective meetings, and the four levels of decision-making on a team. You will also learn about the nine different team roles, how to set effective goals and the six characteristics of a high-performance team.
episodes.title: Establishing Guidelines, Roles and Goals
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:04.078
[SOUND].

2
00:00:04.078 --> 00:00:05.890
Hello, and welcome to BizPro TV.

3
00:00:05.890 --> 00:00:09.749
I'm your host, Peter Vanryanstam, and
today we're continuing in our series about

4
00:00:09.749 --> 00:00:13.660
leading technology teams, and specifically
in this episode, I'm gonna look down so

5
00:00:13.660 --> 00:00:17.144
I get this right, we're talking about
establishing guidelines, roles and

6
00:00:17.144 --> 00:00:18.690
goals for those teams.

7
00:00:18.690 --> 00:00:21.400
And here to help us is someone who has
a lot of experience building teams,

8
00:00:21.400 --> 00:00:21.960
John Spence.

9
00:00:21.960 --> 00:00:22.640
John, how are you doing?

10
00:00:22.640 --> 00:00:23.720
>> Doing great Peter, and you?

11
00:00:23.720 --> 00:00:24.470
>> I'm doing fantastic.

12
00:00:24.470 --> 00:00:25.080
Thank you very much.

13
00:00:25.080 --> 00:00:25.960
>> My pleasure.

14
00:00:25.960 --> 00:00:28.590
>> I think a good place for
us to start today,

15
00:00:28.590 --> 00:00:32.750
we talked a lot in previous episodes about
how we go ahead and build that team.

16
00:00:32.750 --> 00:00:37.500
So let's just do a quick recap of that so
we can kind of get our minds set in this,

17
00:00:37.500 --> 00:00:41.380
and then continue on in talking
about how to establish those goals.

18
00:00:41.380 --> 00:00:46.200
>> Yeah, we used one of the most famous
and well known frameworks about forming,

19
00:00:46.200 --> 00:00:49.490
storming, norming,
performing and adjourning.

20
00:00:49.490 --> 00:00:52.280
Remember that,
[LAUGH] adjourning the team.

21
00:00:52.280 --> 00:00:55.690
And we're still focused on
the forming part here, and

22
00:00:55.690 --> 00:00:57.060
getting sure that we're on track.

23
00:00:57.060 --> 00:01:01.040
And one of the most important
things to do when forming a team

24
00:01:01.040 --> 00:01:04.760
is after you've figured out your purpose,
your direction, your sponsors told you

25
00:01:04.760 --> 00:01:09.890
where you wanna go is to sit back and
say, alright let's create a team charter.

26
00:01:09.890 --> 00:01:10.475
At least that's the word.

27
00:01:10.475 --> 00:01:13.886
It could be a rules for
the road, your team guidelines,

28
00:01:13.886 --> 00:01:16.120
whatever you wanna call it.

29
00:01:16.120 --> 00:01:19.740
But I call it a team charter of, this
is the way we're gonna behave, this is

30
00:01:19.740 --> 00:01:24.160
the way we're gonna act, this is the way
we'll treat each other within the team.

31
00:01:24.160 --> 00:01:26.250
And I brought an example here, Peter,

32
00:01:26.250 --> 00:01:30.540
I wanted to read, because these can
be challenging to put together.

33
00:01:30.540 --> 00:01:33.910
And it should be your whole team
that sits down and discusses this.

34
00:01:33.910 --> 00:01:37.180
But I want to give you a few examples
that I think will help you when you go to

35
00:01:37.180 --> 00:01:38.950
do your guidelines.

36
00:01:38.950 --> 00:01:42.945
So here's a set that I've pulled down
from one of the clients I worked with.

37
00:01:42.945 --> 00:01:46.110
100% respect at all time.

38
00:01:46.110 --> 00:01:50.160
Microsoft's got a great example around
this, they say to be tough on ideas and

39
00:01:50.160 --> 00:01:51.400
easy on people.

40
00:01:51.400 --> 00:01:54.870
So if you're gonna have a highly cohesive
team, you gotta make sure that you treat

41
00:01:54.870 --> 00:01:58.230
each other with the an extremely
high level of respect.

42
00:01:58.230 --> 00:02:02.110
Meetings are a safe place that if we talk
about something that's confidential,

43
00:02:02.110 --> 00:02:06.380
if we share an idea that we don't want
outside of the room that we know that

44
00:02:06.380 --> 00:02:08.980
whatever happens in
the meeting you're safe.

45
00:02:08.980 --> 00:02:10.030
You're not gonna be attacked.

46
00:02:10.030 --> 00:02:13.296
We're not gonna come after you, we're not
gonna embarrass you and we're not gonna

47
00:02:13.296 --> 00:02:16.289
share the things that you said in here
that you'd prefer didn't get shared.

48
00:02:16.289 --> 00:02:20.041
We will communicate the status of
each other's work no matter how bad

49
00:02:20.041 --> 00:02:21.100
the news is.

50
00:02:21.100 --> 00:02:22.600
I love this one.

51
00:02:22.600 --> 00:02:25.630
If you're running late on something, and
you're not gonna turn it in on time,

52
00:02:25.630 --> 00:02:27.800
you don't wait until it's
late to tell everybody.

53
00:02:27.800 --> 00:02:30.436
You tell them, I'm falling behind,
I need a little help,

54
00:02:30.436 --> 00:02:33.197
I'm not gonna be able to get
that to you by Friday at 4:00.

55
00:02:33.197 --> 00:02:37.660
We will speak our mind rather
than hide things from each other.

56
00:02:37.660 --> 00:02:41.380
When we evaluate each others work
our focus will be on work and

57
00:02:41.380 --> 00:02:43.360
not who did it, and that's a big idea.

58
00:02:43.360 --> 00:02:48.970
So kinda goes back to my Microsoft quote,
focus attack ideas but not people.

59
00:02:48.970 --> 00:02:50.430
This is where we're gonna look at it and
say,

60
00:02:50.430 --> 00:02:54.430
this work is not at the quality we wanted,
it's not what we expected, it doesn't

61
00:02:54.430 --> 00:02:58.420
have all the information we required and
I'm not going to attack the person at all.

62
00:02:58.420 --> 00:03:03.270
But as a team, we're gonna agree that
every time we put work out, as a group,

63
00:03:03.270 --> 00:03:07.260
we're gonna make sure the work is up to
par and no one will take it personally.

64
00:03:07.260 --> 00:03:09.510
We will come prepared to meetings.

65
00:03:09.510 --> 00:03:12.580
And in case we are unable to attend,
we will complete our work, and

66
00:03:12.580 --> 00:03:14.580
forward its status to the team leader.

67
00:03:14.580 --> 00:03:17.850
Not every time a team gets together
can all the team members be there.

68
00:03:17.850 --> 00:03:20.290
But you want to make sure that
all the information necessary for

69
00:03:20.290 --> 00:03:21.880
the meeting is there.

70
00:03:21.880 --> 00:03:26.380
Everything's been turned early, people
have a chance to prepare, read, study, and

71
00:03:26.380 --> 00:03:28.520
be able to come to the meeting
set to go immediately.

72
00:03:30.000 --> 00:03:33.829
Here's two more to go on that, we'll
arrive on time and respect the agenda.

73
00:03:33.829 --> 00:03:37.090
We will not have a meeting
unless we have an agenda.

74
00:03:37.090 --> 00:03:38.120
This is a big point.

75
00:03:38.120 --> 00:03:42.440
I see a lot of teams waste time because
they set a 9 o'clock meeting when people

76
00:03:42.440 --> 00:03:44.088
roll in about 9, 9:15.

77
00:03:44.088 --> 00:03:48.260
It was supposed to stop at 10, we don't
have agenda, we're chatting about it.

78
00:03:48.260 --> 00:03:52.350
Really good teams have a clear start time,
a clear stop time,

79
00:03:52.350 --> 00:03:55.990
and they've created an agenda and
everyone stays on agenda.

80
00:03:55.990 --> 00:03:58.890
And if you get something that's off,
you can put it over in a parking lot.

81
00:03:58.890 --> 00:04:02.970
But 80% of the meeting, 90% of
the meeting should be fast, on time,

82
00:04:02.970 --> 00:04:05.320
clear communication, on agenda.

83
00:04:05.320 --> 00:04:07.870
There are a couple more here
I wanna share with you.

84
00:04:07.870 --> 00:04:11.200
We will leave every medium with a clear
action steps, responsibilities and

85
00:04:11.200 --> 00:04:12.230
due dates.

86
00:04:12.230 --> 00:04:16.000
Again, this is another big issue I see
is we have a meeting, we discuss stuff,

87
00:04:16.000 --> 00:04:18.530
we throw some ideas out and
then we get up and walk out.

88
00:04:18.530 --> 00:04:22.290
On an effective team, we stop and
we talk about each idea,

89
00:04:22.290 --> 00:04:25.060
who's gonna take care of it,
who will take the responsibility,

90
00:04:25.060 --> 00:04:28.790
what the outcome looks like, what the due
date is and we'll gain agreement.

91
00:04:28.790 --> 00:04:33.700
And we'll not leave the media until
someone is specifically responsible for

92
00:04:33.700 --> 00:04:37.780
it, and has accepted responsibility and
agreed on a timeline and date, and

93
00:04:37.780 --> 00:04:39.470
you know what the next steps are.

94
00:04:39.470 --> 00:04:42.730
So everyone knows what's gonna
happen after the meeting.

95
00:04:42.730 --> 00:04:45.700
We will practice both personal and
team accountability.

96
00:04:45.700 --> 00:04:49.220
If you didn't do something you
gotta take full accountability.

97
00:04:49.220 --> 00:04:50.880
If someone else didn't,
and here's the tough one,

98
00:04:50.880 --> 00:04:54.580
is we have to have a team that
holds each other accountable.

99
00:04:54.580 --> 00:04:57.930
And that people don't get defensive or
angry or emotional,

100
00:04:57.930 --> 00:05:03.210
that they understand this is us trying
to create a super high performance team.

101
00:05:03.210 --> 00:05:06.130
Which is another role l like is if we're
pushing each other a little hard in

102
00:05:06.130 --> 00:05:09.290
the meeting and we're being
a little aggressive around ideas,

103
00:05:09.290 --> 00:05:13.550
if people do start to get emotional, then
you've got a mandatory ten minute break.

104
00:05:13.550 --> 00:05:17.330
Everybody go just gets a glass of water,
walks outside, has some coffee or

105
00:05:17.330 --> 00:05:21.471
something, but the minute emotions start
to get beyond the point of constructive

106
00:05:21.471 --> 00:05:25.371
conflict, you wanna sort of shut
the meeting down for 10 or 15 minutes and

107
00:05:25.371 --> 00:05:27.011
make sure everything's good.

108
00:05:27.011 --> 00:05:30.149
And then last but not least,
we will respond to email or

109
00:05:30.149 --> 00:05:33.830
phone queries from others on
the team within 24 hours.

110
00:05:33.830 --> 00:05:36.860
If we don't have an answer,
we will at least acknowledge the query

111
00:05:36.860 --> 00:05:40.258
within 24 hours, and let the sender
know about our ability to help.

112
00:05:40.258 --> 00:05:43.340
If you're not communicating with
the rest of the team in a timely manner,

113
00:05:43.340 --> 00:05:45.330
you're holding the rest of the team back.

114
00:05:45.330 --> 00:05:48.814
So making that rule, you've got 24
hours from the minute you get an email,

115
00:05:48.814 --> 00:05:50.500
to either say, I can't respond right now,

116
00:05:50.500 --> 00:05:54.730
I'll get back to you tomorrow, or here's
the answer, let's keep things moving.

117
00:05:54.730 --> 00:05:59.140
>> I think those are a great kind of
list that you could start from and build

118
00:05:59.140 --> 00:06:02.130
your own, or tweak those to accommodate
the kind of project you're own.

119
00:06:02.130 --> 00:06:05.260
But I think it's also important to
note that isn't something that just

120
00:06:05.260 --> 00:06:07.830
comes down from the team leader and
says, these are our rules,

121
00:06:07.830 --> 00:06:11.720
but we gotta get everyone involved and
get that buy in.

122
00:06:11.720 --> 00:06:15.815
>> Yeah, that's really the essential part
of this, is this should be a very robust,

123
00:06:15.815 --> 00:06:19.650
thorough discussion, where you put a lot
of ideas on the table, some of the ones

124
00:06:19.650 --> 00:06:23.150
I just gave you, look some more up on
the internet, whatever you wanna do.

125
00:06:23.150 --> 00:06:27.780
And let people give their ideas, of
the kinda guidelines, rules of the road,

126
00:06:27.780 --> 00:06:31.220
the charter they want, cuz this is
gonna be the bedrock for your team.

127
00:06:31.220 --> 00:06:35.010
This is gonna be the thing that keeps
your performance at a certain level and

128
00:06:35.010 --> 00:06:36.930
helps you interact with each other and

129
00:06:36.930 --> 00:06:40.000
one of the ways I use this,
Peter, is to number it.

130
00:06:40.000 --> 00:06:43.520
Once we come up with a team charter, I
want to put a big number next to each one

131
00:06:43.520 --> 00:06:45.670
so if we're in middle
of a team meeting and

132
00:06:45.670 --> 00:06:51.930
I feel like someone violates one of
the charter ideas, one of the values.

133
00:06:51.930 --> 00:06:54.236
Instead of calling me out I'm still
looking at my piece of paper and go,

134
00:06:54.236 --> 00:06:55.040
number three.

135
00:06:55.040 --> 00:06:56.370
Number three, everybody read it.

136
00:06:56.370 --> 00:06:58.080
Because you should carry
the charter to every meeting.

137
00:06:58.080 --> 00:06:59.670
It should be sitting on the desk so

138
00:06:59.670 --> 00:07:02.780
that any time you interact with people,
you can look down at, and

139
00:07:02.780 --> 00:07:05.380
if you're violating it or if you're
worried about it, and I like that.

140
00:07:05.380 --> 00:07:08.070
So it's a very innocuous way to say,
number seven.

141
00:07:08.070 --> 00:07:09.724
Let's just all take a second
to look at number seven.

142
00:07:09.724 --> 00:07:12.057
>> Yeah, so this isn't something
that's just discussed,

143
00:07:12.057 --> 00:07:15.080
this is actually written down on paper and
brought to meetings.

144
00:07:15.080 --> 00:07:17.668
>> Written down, brought to meetings,
part of the agenda.

145
00:07:17.668 --> 00:07:20.719
Some companies I work have
a couple of them laminated, and

146
00:07:20.719 --> 00:07:23.287
they leave them laying
on the conference table.

147
00:07:23.287 --> 00:07:26.060
And any time you get together,
you just sort of push them around.

148
00:07:26.060 --> 00:07:29.510
Some organizations I work with, actually
read them at the beginning of every team

149
00:07:29.510 --> 00:07:31.660
meeting, to make sure that everybody's on.

150
00:07:31.660 --> 00:07:34.570
They will do the mission, vision,
values of the company and

151
00:07:34.570 --> 00:07:40.100
the team charter as a two or three minute
start up to get everybody refreshed and

152
00:07:40.100 --> 00:07:41.730
make sure we're all on the same page.

153
00:07:41.730 --> 00:07:42.560
>> Okay, now,

154
00:07:42.560 --> 00:07:48.110
one of the next things that we have to
talk about in this episode is the roles.

155
00:07:48.110 --> 00:07:52.162
And I'm curious about how the decision
making process should go within in a team.

156
00:07:52.162 --> 00:07:55.554
Is this something that's unique to
the team or do we always just say, okay,

157
00:07:55.554 --> 00:07:57.627
everyone bring their ideas,
and the leader.

158
00:07:57.627 --> 00:07:59.975
Comes up with what the final decision is?

159
00:07:59.975 --> 00:08:04.570
>> Well, this is something I learned
years ago when I used to run a company.

160
00:08:04.570 --> 00:08:09.510
I was a new CEO and I thought it was so
cool to be in charge.

161
00:08:09.510 --> 00:08:13.239
[LAUGH] And I would sit in my office and
every decision had to come to me.

162
00:08:13.239 --> 00:08:16.450
Until I looked up one day and saw my
entire staff standing in the hallway

163
00:08:16.450 --> 00:08:18.200
waiting for me to make the decisions.

164
00:08:18.200 --> 00:08:20.048
And I realized I was the bottleneck.

165
00:08:20.048 --> 00:08:24.320
So, all of the decisions do not
need to be made by the team leader.

166
00:08:24.320 --> 00:08:27.360
And I came up with an idea called
the four levels of decision making.

167
00:08:27.360 --> 00:08:28.470
So here's how they work.

168
00:08:28.470 --> 00:08:30.490
Level one decision.

169
00:08:30.490 --> 00:08:31.740
No matter who you are on the team.

170
00:08:31.740 --> 00:08:33.430
No matter what role you are playing.

171
00:08:33.430 --> 00:08:34.073
This is your decision.

172
00:08:34.073 --> 00:08:36.350
Now, you're the expert on this.

173
00:08:36.350 --> 00:08:37.950
This is why you're on the team.

174
00:08:37.950 --> 00:08:39.740
You don't need to talk to anybody else.

175
00:08:39.740 --> 00:08:42.010
Make the decision and
then you own the outcome.

176
00:08:42.010 --> 00:08:44.060
You have full accountability for
the outcome.

177
00:08:44.060 --> 00:08:46.917
Level one decision,
you make the decision, you own it.

178
00:08:46.917 --> 00:08:50.460
Level two, you probably need
to get some feedback on this.

179
00:08:50.460 --> 00:08:53.480
Talk to me as a team leader,
talk to someone else on the team,

180
00:08:53.480 --> 00:08:57.070
maybe talk to someone outside of the team,
get some advice, some input,

181
00:08:57.070 --> 00:09:00.490
some suggestions,
then you make the decision and you own it.

182
00:09:00.490 --> 00:09:04.690
Level two, get advice,
you make decision, you own the decision.

183
00:09:04.690 --> 00:09:06.470
Level three is a team decision.

184
00:09:06.470 --> 00:09:09.880
And this is, as you said Peter,
is when we get everybody together.

185
00:09:09.880 --> 00:09:12.150
And we're going to try
to get the consensus.

186
00:09:12.150 --> 00:09:13.730
We're going to put
everybody's idea in there.

187
00:09:13.730 --> 00:09:15.160
We're all going to talk about it.

188
00:09:15.160 --> 00:09:16.880
And then here's the big idea for
the team leader.

189
00:09:17.910 --> 00:09:21.620
Whatever the team decides,
the leader backs it up and

190
00:09:21.620 --> 00:09:23.260
the leader owns the decision.

191
00:09:23.260 --> 00:09:27.280
So if I'm the team leader and the team
says, we all wanna go this way, and I say,

192
00:09:27.280 --> 00:09:28.360
I think we should go this way,

193
00:09:28.360 --> 00:09:31.220
and the whole team says this,
then I say, all right.

194
00:09:31.220 --> 00:09:33.410
I'm gonna go in your direction,
I trust you.

195
00:09:33.410 --> 00:09:34.624
We're on this team together.

196
00:09:34.624 --> 00:09:38.240
We'll make that decision as a team and
then I own the outcome.

197
00:09:38.240 --> 00:09:42.050
If anything goes wrong, I'll take
accountability and responsibility for it.

198
00:09:42.050 --> 00:09:45.582
Which gets me to level four decisions,
which is the team leaders' decision.

199
00:09:45.582 --> 00:09:48.257
And at that level you say
I'm making this decision and

200
00:09:48.257 --> 00:09:50.370
I need everybody else to back me up.

201
00:09:50.370 --> 00:09:54.275
On the level three team decisions you made
the decisions or you guys came up with

202
00:09:54.275 --> 00:09:57.961
what you wanted to do, I followed it and
backed you, I need you to back me.

203
00:09:57.961 --> 00:09:59.837
I might have information you don't have,

204
00:09:59.837 --> 00:10:03.270
I might have a little bit higher
strategic view of what's going on.

205
00:10:03.270 --> 00:10:06.050
I might have better
communications with the sponsor.

206
00:10:06.050 --> 00:10:09.420
But at this level I need to,
you just need to trust me.

207
00:10:09.420 --> 00:10:13.422
And if you've done the other three levels
and you've built a high level of trust,

208
00:10:13.422 --> 00:10:17.482
then what happens is your team, instead of
getting angry or mad or pushing back, or

209
00:10:17.482 --> 00:10:19.351
getting defensive is say, I got you.

210
00:10:19.351 --> 00:10:20.360
I got your back.

211
00:10:20.360 --> 00:10:21.150
You trusted us.

212
00:10:21.150 --> 00:10:24.127
I'll trust you and they get to
work instead of sitting around and

213
00:10:24.127 --> 00:10:25.738
complaining about the decision.

214
00:10:25.738 --> 00:10:28.352
>> That seems to be a theme,
not just with the team charter, but

215
00:10:28.352 --> 00:10:30.070
also with how decisions are made.

216
00:10:30.070 --> 00:10:33.710
We wanna get buy-in from the entire group,
and speaking of that group.

217
00:10:33.710 --> 00:10:35.314
So we just talked about the leader,

218
00:10:35.314 --> 00:10:38.844
that's kind of the role that everyone
already knows that exists on a team, but

219
00:10:38.844 --> 00:10:41.964
there are other roles just besides
leader and non-leader, right?

220
00:10:41.964 --> 00:10:43.670
>> Believe it or not, yeah.

221
00:10:43.670 --> 00:10:48.470
This is an area that frankly,
I'm not used to working in a whole bunch.

222
00:10:48.470 --> 00:10:52.081
Because most of the time teams have sort
of formed and they're going together.

223
00:10:52.081 --> 00:10:57.140
So I had to do a little research on this,
and I found a model by Meredith Belbin.

224
00:10:57.140 --> 00:10:59.710
I'm gonna go ahead and
move to a slide here if we could.

225
00:10:59.710 --> 00:11:05.000
And this is the nine roles of a team and
I thought this was some very good work.

226
00:11:05.000 --> 00:11:07.732
So I wanna go through these quickly and
we'll hit them.

227
00:11:07.732 --> 00:11:10.820
So the first one we're gonna look at
is the people focus part of the team.

228
00:11:10.820 --> 00:11:12.130
What do the people do together?

229
00:11:12.130 --> 00:11:14.270
And you've got three general areas there.

230
00:11:14.270 --> 00:11:18.190
You've got your resource Investigator,
which is the person that's going out and

231
00:11:18.190 --> 00:11:19.260
trying to get help.

232
00:11:19.260 --> 00:11:21.270
They're asking for input,
they're asking for

233
00:11:21.270 --> 00:11:23.430
resources, they're trying
to get information.

234
00:11:23.430 --> 00:11:26.225
They're trying to do everything they
can to bring more resources and

235
00:11:26.225 --> 00:11:27.198
bring them to the team.

236
00:11:27.198 --> 00:11:31.320
Next one is what they call team worker,
and this is pretty easy.

237
00:11:31.320 --> 00:11:35.470
This is the sociable person on
the team that energizes the team,

238
00:11:35.470 --> 00:11:37.780
keeps them motivated, keeps them together.

239
00:11:37.780 --> 00:11:40.687
Smooths out conflict,
make sure people aren't fighting,

240
00:11:40.687 --> 00:11:44.630
they're the one's that want to make sure
the team's cohesive and it gets along.

241
00:11:44.630 --> 00:11:46.760
The next one is the coordinator.

242
00:11:46.760 --> 00:11:48.810
And with the coordinators
it's kinda like the agenda.

243
00:11:48.810 --> 00:11:52.340
It's keeping people on goal,
on time, on date.

244
00:11:52.340 --> 00:11:55.780
Making sure they're coordinated in all
the different parts of the project and

245
00:11:55.780 --> 00:11:58.659
keeping everyone on the team
focused on delivering the results.

246
00:11:58.659 --> 00:12:01.670
So those first three
are all-around people focused.

247
00:12:01.670 --> 00:12:04.345
>> And just to clarify while you're
going to the next slide here,

248
00:12:04.345 --> 00:12:07.235
are we saying that every team needs
to have all of these components.

249
00:12:07.235 --> 00:12:09.782
Or are we saying that these
are kind of the buckets

250
00:12:09.782 --> 00:12:13.980
that you can kind of put people in your
mind so you know how to work with them?

251
00:12:13.980 --> 00:12:15.530
>> Superb question.

252
00:12:15.530 --> 00:12:17.320
These are sort of the buckets
you can put them in.

253
00:12:17.320 --> 00:12:18.458
And different people play different roles.

254
00:12:18.458 --> 00:12:21.880
Like in a minute we're gonna
talk about the specialist.

255
00:12:21.880 --> 00:12:24.920
And I might be the specialist in
one part of the team project and

256
00:12:24.920 --> 00:12:26.370
then someone else is a specialist.

257
00:12:26.370 --> 00:12:28.352
So you don't always wanna
be the coordinator.

258
00:12:28.352 --> 00:12:32.670
You don't always wanna be the team worker,
although you want everybody in the team.

259
00:12:32.670 --> 00:12:36.300
But it would be tiring if you were
the one that constantly had to go

260
00:12:36.300 --> 00:12:37.130
smooth the waters.

261
00:12:37.130 --> 00:12:38.230
Make sure everybody is right.

262
00:12:38.230 --> 00:12:39.740
Get between people.

263
00:12:39.740 --> 00:12:43.260
So these roles rotate according to
where people are on the team and

264
00:12:43.260 --> 00:12:45.100
where the team is in its project.

265
00:12:45.100 --> 00:12:49.206
Give you a good example here, the first
one we're gonna talk about in under action

266
00:12:49.206 --> 00:12:52.432
and task focus is the shaper and
oftentimes that's the leader.

267
00:12:52.432 --> 00:12:55.992
The visionary whose setting the strategy,
identifying the course for

268
00:12:55.992 --> 00:12:58.017
the organization, where we want to go.

269
00:12:58.017 --> 00:13:00.833
We said earlier, and
we're gonna talk about it in a minute,

270
00:13:00.833 --> 00:13:03.850
it's really important on a team for
that to be shared.

271
00:13:03.850 --> 00:13:07.630
But there is a role for someone who's
gonna say this is where we're all going.

272
00:13:07.630 --> 00:13:11.530
Let's get excited, let's get aligned,
here's where I see our team going.

273
00:13:11.530 --> 00:13:13.176
The next one is the Implementer.

274
00:13:13.176 --> 00:13:17.498
And this is critical on a team, because
the single biggest problem in most teams

275
00:13:17.498 --> 00:13:21.059
and organizations I work with Is
lack of disciplined execution.

276
00:13:21.059 --> 00:13:23.200
They've got great ideas.

277
00:13:23.200 --> 00:13:24.280
They've got a good strategy.

278
00:13:24.280 --> 00:13:24.948
They've got a plan.

279
00:13:24.948 --> 00:13:29.010
They've got a vision, but
it's not being implemented accordingly.

280
00:13:29.010 --> 00:13:31.640
So the implementer is
someone who's pushing,

281
00:13:31.640 --> 00:13:35.720
who's moving things forward, making sure
they take ideas and turn them into action.

282
00:13:35.720 --> 00:13:37.722
They're results focused all the time.

283
00:13:37.722 --> 00:13:41.973
The completer and finisher is the one
that once you've got the stuff quote on

284
00:13:41.973 --> 00:13:45.510
quote finished, [LAUGH] they go in and
make sure it's right.

285
00:13:45.510 --> 00:13:47.100
That there's no errors.

286
00:13:47.100 --> 00:13:49.180
That you've covered everything
you needed to cover.

287
00:13:49.180 --> 00:13:52.700
That it's on time and you deliver
what you promised you would deliver.

288
00:13:52.700 --> 00:13:54.760
So again people are gonna
switch in those roles Peter.

289
00:13:54.760 --> 00:13:56.810
Sometimes I'm gonna be the finisher.

290
00:13:56.810 --> 00:13:59.820
If I understand the project
better than anyone else.

291
00:13:59.820 --> 00:14:01.590
I'll be the one that goes through and
checks for errors,

292
00:14:01.590 --> 00:14:04.390
omissions and
makes sure that everything's on target.

293
00:14:04.390 --> 00:14:06.330
>> All right, so
we've done people focused.

294
00:14:06.330 --> 00:14:08.780
We've done action and task focused.

295
00:14:08.780 --> 00:14:09.700
So what's next?

296
00:14:09.700 --> 00:14:13.230
>> We're gonna move to thinking focused,
and again there's nine roles, so

297
00:14:13.230 --> 00:14:14.370
there's three here.

298
00:14:14.370 --> 00:14:18.870
It's an interesting name when I looked at
this research by Dolbin, the word plant,

299
00:14:18.870 --> 00:14:20.970
and I had to think about this for
a minute.

300
00:14:20.970 --> 00:14:24.841
And the plant is sort of the person you
plant in the team who's innovative,

301
00:14:24.841 --> 00:14:27.805
creative, who's gonna may
be play devil's advocate.

302
00:14:27.805 --> 00:14:30.430
They're gonna push people
a little bit harder.

303
00:14:30.430 --> 00:14:33.600
They're the one that are gonna
test ideas,and try to bring in

304
00:14:33.600 --> 00:14:37.720
different thinking, new ideas,
different ways to look at things.

305
00:14:37.720 --> 00:14:40.700
And mix things up, and
keep the team innovative and creative.

306
00:14:40.700 --> 00:14:43.889
And again different people
play this role all the time.

307
00:14:43.889 --> 00:14:47.710
The specialist is the person
who has unique knowledge.

308
00:14:47.710 --> 00:14:49.860
They've got an expertise, experience,

309
00:14:49.860 --> 00:14:53.100
training in an area that no
one else on the team has.

310
00:14:53.100 --> 00:14:55.790
So they've got a lot more than
the other people on the team and

311
00:14:55.790 --> 00:14:57.070
we turn to the specialist.

312
00:14:57.070 --> 00:15:01.204
And again the role rotates according to
what the project's trying to achieve and

313
00:15:01.204 --> 00:15:05.116
the person who has the best experience,
the most information in that area.

314
00:15:05.116 --> 00:15:07.673
And then, last, is the monitor evaluator,

315
00:15:07.673 --> 00:15:10.540
who's always looking at options,
all right?

316
00:15:10.540 --> 00:15:12.724
Cuz what happens a lot is
you get groupthink and

317
00:15:12.724 --> 00:15:15.246
it's an interesting thing
I learned a long time ago.

318
00:15:15.246 --> 00:15:19.481
And you'll probably enjoy this, Peter, is
I realized one day that almost throughout

319
00:15:19.481 --> 00:15:22.614
your entire life when you're
in kindergarten, grade school,

320
00:15:22.614 --> 00:15:27.170
graduate school, whatever it is, you're
taught to look for the one right answer.

321
00:15:27.170 --> 00:15:29.720
Cuz on every test,
there's always one right answer.

322
00:15:29.720 --> 00:15:32.230
But the minute you get out of school and
you get into the work, you realize

323
00:15:32.230 --> 00:15:35.730
there's not always one right answer,
there could be multiple right answers.

324
00:15:35.730 --> 00:15:40.030
So what the monitor evaluator is doing is
constantly trying to evaluate options.

325
00:15:40.030 --> 00:15:42.661
Make sure things are going,
offer more options and

326
00:15:42.661 --> 00:15:44.863
make sure that we don't
get group think and

327
00:15:44.863 --> 00:15:48.613
settle on the very first idea because
we think it's the one best answer.

328
00:15:48.613 --> 00:15:52.412
That we go to a second, and a third, and
a fourth option and then usually find out

329
00:15:52.412 --> 00:15:56.247
that if we combine number three and number
one it comes out with a better answer.

330
00:15:56.247 --> 00:15:59.986
>> So what, we might not have
one of each of those nine roles.

331
00:15:59.986 --> 00:16:03.354
We might not even have nine
individual people on the team,

332
00:16:03.354 --> 00:16:07.683
could be a smaller team than that, it
might be a good idea to have people kind

333
00:16:07.683 --> 00:16:10.111
of in each of those overall three groups.

334
00:16:10.111 --> 00:16:13.671
>> Yeah, I want a good mix on my team,
of people that can do all of those things.

335
00:16:13.671 --> 00:16:17.395
And then sometimes, you can assign
one of these roles, for example,

336
00:16:17.395 --> 00:16:21.120
you can tell someone that their job's
gonna be to bring in the second,

337
00:16:21.120 --> 00:16:24.466
third, fourth idea,
to be the creative, innovative one, or

338
00:16:24.466 --> 00:16:28.569
you can assign someone to be the one that
keeps everybody on time and agenda and

339
00:16:28.569 --> 00:16:31.887
makes sure that things are going
forward the way they need to.

340
00:16:31.887 --> 00:16:36.980
So it's gonna be, some people will fall
into these on their own, other times,

341
00:16:36.980 --> 00:16:42.020
you can assign the role and say, for now
I want you to play this role on the team.

342
00:16:42.020 --> 00:16:45.976
>> All right, great, John, that covers the
roles now, and now we're gonna move on to

343
00:16:45.976 --> 00:16:49.230
the goals I guess, everything has
to rhyme with you, it seems like.

344
00:16:49.230 --> 00:16:50.493
>> [LAUGH]
>> Roles and goals, so

345
00:16:50.493 --> 00:16:51.855
tell us about the goals on a team.

346
00:16:51.855 --> 00:16:56.102
>> Well, now that we've understood
the different roles people can play,

347
00:16:56.102 --> 00:17:00.905
before you set the goals, you wanna step
back and reconfirm what's our purpose,

348
00:17:00.905 --> 00:17:03.985
what does success look like,
what's the outcome?

349
00:17:03.985 --> 00:17:07.508
Because all the goals are going to
be driven by the final outcome, and

350
00:17:07.508 --> 00:17:11.641
one of the reasons it's so important to
set that direction together is it's part

351
00:17:11.641 --> 00:17:15.893
of a model that I teach, that I've studied
and learned about what it takes to create

352
00:17:15.893 --> 00:17:20.445
a high performance team, and there's six
things on that, and we'll go through them.

353
00:17:20.445 --> 00:17:24.759
Number one is direction, going back and
checking on what are the overall goals,

354
00:17:24.759 --> 00:17:26.991
the outcomes, what do we wanna achieve?

355
00:17:26.991 --> 00:17:31.326
And the key word on high performance
teams with direction is shared,

356
00:17:31.326 --> 00:17:35.528
people need to have a chance to
give their ideas, their opinions.

357
00:17:35.528 --> 00:17:38.390
That doesn't mean they get to
change the overall objective and

358
00:17:38.390 --> 00:17:42.062
purpose of the team, the overall major
goal for the team or major objective, but

359
00:17:42.062 --> 00:17:45.410
they need to have a chance to say,
here's how I think we should get there,

360
00:17:45.410 --> 00:17:49.216
this is what I'm interested in, here's
some things that we might wanna focus on.

361
00:17:49.216 --> 00:17:52.258
One of the ways I look at it is if
people don't have a say in the outcome,

362
00:17:52.258 --> 00:17:54.990
they wont have a stake in the outcome,
if the leader just says,

363
00:17:54.990 --> 00:17:58.395
this is what we're doing, this is where
we're going, these are the values,

364
00:17:58.395 --> 00:18:01.489
this is our culture, and you are not
getting a lot of bind on your team and

365
00:18:01.489 --> 00:18:04.169
in order to have a great technology team,
or any kind of team,

366
00:18:04.169 --> 00:18:06.482
you need people committed and
aligned and excited.

367
00:18:06.482 --> 00:18:10.776
So the first D in my model,
and the model is DMCCMD, so

368
00:18:10.776 --> 00:18:15.548
the first D is direction,
the first M is measurable goals,

369
00:18:15.548 --> 00:18:19.938
which is exactly what we
are going to get into here, and

370
00:18:19.938 --> 00:18:23.566
the idea behind measurable
goals is binary,

371
00:18:23.566 --> 00:18:27.601
you want the goal to be very clear,
no ambiguity.

372
00:18:27.601 --> 00:18:32.375
One of my very, very favorite business
phrases is ambiguity breeds mediocrity, so

373
00:18:32.375 --> 00:18:36.138
we want the goals to be as specific and
clear as possible, binary,

374
00:18:36.138 --> 00:18:41.248
it's a one-zero, yes-no, you've got it or
you didn't, no guessing, everybody can

375
00:18:41.248 --> 00:18:46.129
clearly understand it, you're gonna see
why that's so important in just a minute.

376
00:18:46.129 --> 00:18:50.398
The first C is competence, I want to get
the very best people I can possibly get on

377
00:18:50.398 --> 00:18:54.671
my team, I want people who are highly
competent, who understand what they're

378
00:18:54.671 --> 00:18:58.047
doing, have a lot of experience and
are good at being on a team,

379
00:18:58.047 --> 00:19:02.237
that are collaborative, so I wanna get
highly competent people on the team.

380
00:19:02.237 --> 00:19:07.666
The next C is communication, and the key
words around communication are open,

381
00:19:07.666 --> 00:19:11.646
honest, robust, and
the major key word is transparent.

382
00:19:11.646 --> 00:19:16.902
On a high functioning team,
people are constantly sharing information.

383
00:19:16.902 --> 00:19:20.121
People used to believe a long time
ago that knowledge equaled power,

384
00:19:20.121 --> 00:19:23.351
that is not it at all, and
especially on a team, that doesn't work.

385
00:19:23.351 --> 00:19:27.098
The more information you share with
people, the better you can empower them,

386
00:19:27.098 --> 00:19:30.958
and that creates a more cohesive team that
the team together is more powerful, so

387
00:19:30.958 --> 00:19:33.946
let me stop there and
review before we get through the first M.

388
00:19:33.946 --> 00:19:37.831
We want to have a clear,
vivid, compelling vision for

389
00:19:37.831 --> 00:19:41.133
the team that is shared,
a shared direction.

390
00:19:41.133 --> 00:19:45.355
The next thing is we want measurable goals
that are binary, we want highly competent

391
00:19:45.355 --> 00:19:48.815
people on the team, and
we want lots of transparent communication.

392
00:19:48.815 --> 00:19:51.634
Now, the second M here is
where the whole model changes,

393
00:19:51.634 --> 00:19:55.645
this is where all the power in the model
is, and this M is mutual accountability.

394
00:19:55.645 --> 00:19:59.778
This is where everybody on the team holds
themselves personally accountable for

395
00:19:59.778 --> 00:20:03.850
delivering whatever they had promised,
and they hold everyone else on the team

396
00:20:03.850 --> 00:20:06.423
accountable for
delivering what they promised.

397
00:20:06.423 --> 00:20:10.392
Now we're going to understand why the
measurable binary goals are so important,

398
00:20:10.392 --> 00:20:13.728
because if you don't have clear goals,
if the goals are ambiguous,

399
00:20:13.728 --> 00:20:17.178
it sounds like this, Peter,
I don't think you achieved that goal, or

400
00:20:17.178 --> 00:20:20.628
I don't think you delivered what
you were supposed to deliver, Mary,

401
00:20:20.628 --> 00:20:24.113
that doesn't seem like you really got
what we wanted to get out of that.

402
00:20:24.113 --> 00:20:24.801
>> I've heard that so much.

403
00:20:24.801 --> 00:20:27.953
>> [LAUGH] I'm sure you have.

404
00:20:27.953 --> 00:20:32.616
If you've got the measurable goals that
are binary, there's not think, no feel nor

405
00:20:32.616 --> 00:20:37.149
opinion, they either got it or they
didn't, that takes out emotion, politics,

406
00:20:37.149 --> 00:20:40.774
personality, now it's not me versus
the other person on my team,

407
00:20:40.774 --> 00:20:44.078
it's the entire team working
together towards the goal, so

408
00:20:44.078 --> 00:20:48.398
it's not me versus you, it's you and
me together versus achieving the goal.

409
00:20:48.398 --> 00:20:50.805
A big idea that helps
a team stay cohesive, and

410
00:20:50.805 --> 00:20:53.832
you can have some constructive
conflict around that, but

411
00:20:53.832 --> 00:20:56.942
it won't elevate all the way
into high levels of conflict.

412
00:20:56.942 --> 00:21:00.142
>> And again, going back to
the other two points we've done so

413
00:21:00.142 --> 00:21:03.343
far before goals,
it's about accountability again, and

414
00:21:03.343 --> 00:21:07.584
making sure we get buy in from everybody
on the team about what these goals are.

415
00:21:07.584 --> 00:21:09.006
>> Yeah, and you said it perfectly.

416
00:21:09.006 --> 00:21:12.103
It's about accountability,
alignment, commitment, and clarity,

417
00:21:12.103 --> 00:21:15.654
we want to make sure that we're all moving
together and we're all on the same team,

418
00:21:15.654 --> 00:21:18.163
which brings me to the final one,
and I'll do them again.

419
00:21:18.163 --> 00:21:21.286
Direction shared, measurements binary,
competent people,

420
00:21:21.286 --> 00:21:25.104
communications are transparent,
now we're going mutual accountability,

421
00:21:25.104 --> 00:21:28.627
where we're all holding each other
accountable, and the last one is D,

422
00:21:28.627 --> 00:21:32.729
the discipline to actually make sure that
your team performs like this all the time,

423
00:21:32.729 --> 00:21:36.889
that they're on point, they're focused,
they've got those first five in order,

424
00:21:36.889 --> 00:21:40.370
they're doing them very well, and
here's what typically happens.

425
00:21:40.370 --> 00:21:44.845
On a mediocre team, a semi-dysfunctional
team, when there's an emergency, a fire,

426
00:21:44.845 --> 00:21:48.963
they can run together and they work great
together, and they do all these things,

427
00:21:48.963 --> 00:21:53.440
they communicate, they help, everyone uses
their expertise and they put out the fire,

428
00:21:53.440 --> 00:21:55.792
and then they go back to
being a mediocre team.

429
00:21:55.792 --> 00:21:59.905
On a high performance team, 90% of
the time they operate at high performance,

430
00:21:59.905 --> 00:22:02.588
they're doing really well,
great communication,

431
00:22:02.588 --> 00:22:04.214
all the things we talked about.

432
00:22:04.214 --> 00:22:08.436
10% of the time they'll start to fail and
not do as well and then they pull

433
00:22:08.436 --> 00:22:12.740
themselves right back up because of
the discipline around this on the team.

434
00:22:12.740 --> 00:22:15.841
>> All right, so John,
now we hive a high performance team and

435
00:22:15.841 --> 00:22:18.763
we're about to set goals, so
what does that look like?

436
00:22:18.763 --> 00:22:23.335
>> Yeah, basically what we're doing here
is creating a strategic plan for the team,

437
00:22:23.335 --> 00:22:27.011
and just like any strategic plan,
there's a general framework.

438
00:22:27.011 --> 00:22:30.577
If you're going to set a strategy, the
first thing is to have your clear vision,

439
00:22:30.577 --> 00:22:32.896
your purpose,
what's the direction for the team?

440
00:22:32.896 --> 00:22:36.687
And we've talked about that many times,
because without a clear direction,

441
00:22:36.687 --> 00:22:38.823
there's no way the team can be successful.

442
00:22:38.823 --> 00:22:42.014
Once you've got that overall purpose,
the outcome you wanna get to,

443
00:22:42.014 --> 00:22:45.872
then you wanna back up and say, all right,
what are three or four major objectives?

444
00:22:45.872 --> 00:22:50.454
What are key, fundamental elements
of making sure we can deliver this?

445
00:22:50.454 --> 00:22:54.523
So you wanna break it into three or fours
sort of subprojects within the entire

446
00:22:54.523 --> 00:22:58.843
project, what I call major objectives,
under each one of those major objectives

447
00:22:58.843 --> 00:23:03.162
then is when we start setting clear goals,
and there's, again, a framework for

448
00:23:03.162 --> 00:23:06.043
this, there's frameworks for
all these things, and

449
00:23:06.043 --> 00:23:10.650
probably one you've heard before is smart
goals, and here's what smart stands for.

450
00:23:10.650 --> 00:23:15.725
The S stands for specific,
clear measurable, key result areas, and

451
00:23:15.725 --> 00:23:21.329
again, binary, so you want very specific,
clear goals with no ambiguity.

452
00:23:21.329 --> 00:23:25.744
The M stands for measurable,
we wanna put numbers on that, due dates,

453
00:23:25.744 --> 00:23:30.305
everything we can do to make sure,
again, that there's no guessing, so

454
00:23:30.305 --> 00:23:32.824
there's specific with measurements.

455
00:23:32.824 --> 00:23:36.696
The A stands for, and I changed this
one a little bit, is agreed upon,

456
00:23:36.696 --> 00:23:40.501
a lot of other folks would use the word
attainable, I think on a team,

457
00:23:40.501 --> 00:23:43.456
if we're all gonna work
towards a goal together, and

458
00:23:43.456 --> 00:23:47.161
we're all gonna be on the same team,
we need to agree on the goals.

459
00:23:47.161 --> 00:23:51.775
The R stands for reasonable, and this
is where you look at it and say, can I

460
00:23:51.775 --> 00:23:56.987
actually achieve this goal, am I willing
to commit to it, do I have the resources,

461
00:23:56.987 --> 00:24:01.392
do I have the people, do I have
the technology, do I have enough time?

462
00:24:01.392 --> 00:24:05.446
And if someone tries to assign or create
a goal that's just unreasonable, then it

463
00:24:05.446 --> 00:24:09.697
automatically puts people frustrated, it
puts the team pitted against each other.

464
00:24:09.697 --> 00:24:12.675
And of course they're not gonna be able
to deliver an unreasonable goal, so

465
00:24:12.675 --> 00:24:14.960
it's gonna hurt the team
progress all the way.

466
00:24:14.960 --> 00:24:17.410
And then last but not least is time down.

467
00:24:17.410 --> 00:24:19.510
It's gotta have a due date.

468
00:24:19.510 --> 00:24:25.350
A goal without a due date is just a wish,
hoping that we can implement our strategy.

469
00:24:25.350 --> 00:24:27.727
And as I like to say,
hope is not a strategy.

470
00:24:27.727 --> 00:24:31.466
>> All right, so I feel like a broken
record here talking about accountability,

471
00:24:31.466 --> 00:24:34.695
but once we've created these goals
as a team and used those models,

472
00:24:34.695 --> 00:24:36.500
who's accountable for the goals?

473
00:24:36.500 --> 00:24:38.870
Is it just the leader of
the team that's accountable?

474
00:24:38.870 --> 00:24:41.900
Or every individual has goals
that they're accountable for.

475
00:24:41.900 --> 00:24:45.096
>> Yeah, what we're going to do is,
the leader of the team is accountable for

476
00:24:45.096 --> 00:24:47.690
the overall success of
the project no matter what.

477
00:24:47.690 --> 00:24:51.460
There always has to be one person that's
accountable for delivering the outcome.

478
00:24:51.460 --> 00:24:55.491
But now what we're going to do is we're
going to be assigning accountability

479
00:24:55.491 --> 00:24:59.335
to different people on the team to finish
their goals that go up to the major

480
00:24:59.335 --> 00:25:00.089
objectives.

481
00:25:00.089 --> 00:25:01.485
I've got a major objective here,

482
00:25:01.485 --> 00:25:04.600
something that's core to the strategy
of achieving what we want.

483
00:25:04.600 --> 00:25:06.760
Underneath that I'm gonna
have a set of goals, and

484
00:25:06.760 --> 00:25:10.610
then each one of those goals will have
one person who's accountable for it.

485
00:25:10.610 --> 00:25:14.830
And one of the reasons I think that's
critical is, is I want the person who's

486
00:25:14.830 --> 00:25:20.920
accountable for it to actually set
the tasks and the action steps themselves.

487
00:25:20.920 --> 00:25:22.460
Again, I want them to own it.

488
00:25:22.460 --> 00:25:25.990
So instead of saying this is your goal and
this is when it's due and here's

489
00:25:25.990 --> 00:25:30.040
the actions I want you to take, we agree
this is the goal, this is when it's due.

490
00:25:30.040 --> 00:25:33.330
And then I'm, as the one is has to
implement it, is gonna sit down and

491
00:25:33.330 --> 00:25:36.170
create a little plan to say all right,
here's what I need to do.

492
00:25:36.170 --> 00:25:37.070
Here's the resources.

493
00:25:37.070 --> 00:25:38.650
Here's my own timeline.

494
00:25:38.650 --> 00:25:44.480
Here's my project milestones so that I can
figure out specifically which tasks and

495
00:25:44.480 --> 00:25:48.370
action steps make sense to allow
me to achieve what I need to do on

496
00:25:48.370 --> 00:25:51.670
the task I've been assigned that
I'm taking full accountability for.

497
00:25:51.670 --> 00:25:55.642
>> Great, okay so
we've covered a lot in this episode.

498
00:25:55.642 --> 00:25:57.794
Can you kind of wrap things up for us and

499
00:25:57.794 --> 00:26:01.120
give us some final
thoughts to remember here?

500
00:26:01.120 --> 00:26:03.760
>> Yeah, I think when you
look at setting the goals for

501
00:26:03.760 --> 00:26:06.000
the team, there's a couple of key ideas.

502
00:26:06.000 --> 00:26:09.182
Number one, it's got to have full
alignment on the outcome, the deliverable.

503
00:26:09.182 --> 00:26:12.592
Whatever the sponsor has tasked you with,
we got to clearly understand,

504
00:26:12.592 --> 00:26:15.460
this is what the entire team
needs to do to get there.

505
00:26:15.460 --> 00:26:19.390
You wanna look at those six key elements
of a high performance team, and

506
00:26:19.390 --> 00:26:22.320
I'm gonna especially
emphasize the communication.

507
00:26:22.320 --> 00:26:26.190
The transparent communication,
helping each other, sharing lots of stuff.

508
00:26:26.190 --> 00:26:29.500
And then last but not least, you've gotta
make sure that if you're gonna get there,

509
00:26:29.500 --> 00:26:32.610
you've gotta have a high level of
accountability, of mutual accountability,

510
00:26:32.610 --> 00:26:34.025
across the entire team.

511
00:26:34.025 --> 00:26:35.846
To actually deliver what
you promised to deliver.

512
00:26:35.846 --> 00:26:40.810
>> All right, great John, I appreciate it
and that's a lot of great information,

513
00:26:40.810 --> 00:26:43.840
but also a good spot for us to go
ahead and wrap up for this episode.

514
00:26:43.840 --> 00:26:46.725
So, we're going to go ahead and
sign off for Biz Pro TV.

515
00:26:46.725 --> 00:26:48.194
I'm your host Peter Van Rysdam.

516
00:26:48.194 --> 00:26:51.102
I'm John Spence, and
we'll see you next time.

517
00:26:51.102 --> 00:27:01.102
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this session you will look at why having a strong culture is so critical to the success of the team. You will also explore what top talent looks for when they join a team, the key characteristics of a winning culture, and the five dysfunctions that can kill a team.
episodes.title: Developing a Team and its Culture
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:04.209
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:04.209 --> 00:00:06.520
Hello, and welcome to BizProTV.

3
00:00:06.520 --> 00:00:08.206
I'm your host Peter VanRysdam,

4
00:00:08.206 --> 00:00:12.067
and today we're continuing in our
series about leading technology teams.

5
00:00:12.067 --> 00:00:16.375
And we're specifically talking about,
how to develop a team and it's culture.

6
00:00:16.375 --> 00:00:19.115
And here to help us, we are very
fortunate to have Mr John Spence.

7
00:00:19.115 --> 00:00:19.815
John, how you doing?

8
00:00:19.815 --> 00:00:20.695
>> Great, Peter, and you?

9
00:00:20.695 --> 00:00:22.645
>> I'm fantastic, thank you.

10
00:00:22.645 --> 00:00:23.174
I think,

11
00:00:23.174 --> 00:00:27.681
a great place to start here is just how do
we define culture as it relates to a team?

12
00:00:27.681 --> 00:00:29.705
>> Yeah, well it's an interesting thing.

13
00:00:29.705 --> 00:00:32.935
There's some people that say
that culture just emerges.

14
00:00:32.935 --> 00:00:38.170
It's the way the folks on the team act,
and treat each other and behave.

15
00:00:38.170 --> 00:00:42.130
So, at its basis, culture's all
about how do we do work together,

16
00:00:42.130 --> 00:00:45.910
how will we treat each other,
what's the main motivators for our team.

17
00:00:45.910 --> 00:00:49.260
So, it's a lot around,
this is the way we're gonna act, and

18
00:00:49.260 --> 00:00:52.550
behave with each other, with our clients,
our customers, our sponsors.

19
00:00:52.550 --> 00:00:54.910
This is the way we do business together.

20
00:00:54.910 --> 00:00:57.970
>> Okay.
Now, why is it very important for

21
00:00:57.970 --> 00:01:00.440
us to have a culture that's so
great in a team.

22
00:01:00.440 --> 00:01:02.970
I mean, it sounds like
a loaded question there, but

23
00:01:02.970 --> 00:01:06.080
it's not something we should just take for
granted.

24
00:01:06.080 --> 00:01:07.790
>> No.
It's not something you can take for

25
00:01:07.790 --> 00:01:08.770
granted, and here's why.

26
00:01:09.810 --> 00:01:14.260
In my 20 years of working with companies
all over the world, there's place,

27
00:01:14.260 --> 00:01:16.830
you can look at them, and they might
be able to improve their manufacturing

28
00:01:16.830 --> 00:01:19.100
a little bi,t or buy some new equipment,
or new technology,

29
00:01:19.100 --> 00:01:23.520
or maybe capture a little bit more market
share, but the single greatest place

30
00:01:23.520 --> 00:01:26.940
that makes, or breaks most
organizations is their culture.

31
00:01:26.940 --> 00:01:30.760
Peter Drucker, who's one of the most
famous management gurus of all time,

32
00:01:30.760 --> 00:01:34.020
said culture each strategy for breakfast.

33
00:01:34.020 --> 00:01:35.260
You can have great equipment.

34
00:01:35.260 --> 00:01:36.490
You can have a cool strategy.

35
00:01:36.490 --> 00:01:39.610
You can even have good people, but
if you have a dysfunctional culture

36
00:01:39.610 --> 00:01:43.040
they will not deliver the business
results that are needed.

37
00:01:43.040 --> 00:01:48.370
So, a strong positive culture is one of
the major drivers of success on a team and

38
00:01:48.370 --> 00:01:50.050
in an entire organization.

39
00:01:50.050 --> 00:01:52.170
>> So, it's kind of the bottom
of the pyramid, if you will,

40
00:01:52.170 --> 00:01:58.150
in terms of the foundation for the rest
of those ingredients in a business.

41
00:01:58.150 --> 00:02:01.540
Now, when you're creating these teams,
and putting them together,

42
00:02:01.540 --> 00:02:05.000
we've talked a lot in previous episodes
about setting goals and things like that.

43
00:02:05.000 --> 00:02:06.220
Who sets this culture?

44
00:02:06.220 --> 00:02:08.370
Is it organic, does it set itself?

45
00:02:08.370 --> 00:02:10.560
Or is it something that's
agreed upon with the team?

46
00:02:10.560 --> 00:02:12.460
>> Absolutely fantastic question.

47
00:02:12.460 --> 00:02:14.040
There are some people, and

48
00:02:14.040 --> 00:02:19.000
I mentioned this briefly earlier, that
say that team culture's just discovered.

49
00:02:19.000 --> 00:02:20.570
That it shapes itself.

50
00:02:20.570 --> 00:02:22.710
That the people on the team
create the culture.

51
00:02:22.710 --> 00:02:25.180
And, I think, to some degree that's true.

52
00:02:25.180 --> 00:02:25.900
But, I also think,

53
00:02:25.900 --> 00:02:30.370
that the team leader has the opportunity
to set some standards around the culture.

54
00:02:31.570 --> 00:02:37.660
Around trust, respect, communication,
things like that, that are non negotiable.

55
00:02:37.660 --> 00:02:39.520
That these are gonna be
part of our culture.

56
00:02:39.520 --> 00:02:42.880
We're gonna treat each other like family,
we're gonna have fun, and

57
00:02:42.880 --> 00:02:45.730
I'm gonna give you some
more examples on this.

58
00:02:45.730 --> 00:02:47.170
So, I think it's two ways, Peter.

59
00:02:47.170 --> 00:02:50.790
I think, that partially the team
just creates the culture

60
00:02:50.790 --> 00:02:54.860
by the way they treat each other, and
the way they want to do business together.

61
00:02:54.860 --> 00:02:55.470
But, I also believe,

62
00:02:55.470 --> 00:02:59.310
that the team leader has an opportunity
to set some fundamental,

63
00:02:59.310 --> 00:03:04.700
core values on the culture that everyone
on the team has to follow those.

64
00:03:04.700 --> 00:03:07.140
Whether they got to choose them or not,

65
00:03:07.140 --> 00:03:09.680
because it's just the way
any team must work together.

66
00:03:09.680 --> 00:03:12.670
>> And while it's great to write some
of those things down, I imagine,

67
00:03:12.670 --> 00:03:17.830
some of that could also be just set
by the leader leading by example.

68
00:03:17.830 --> 00:03:20.810
I think, a lot of people might look to
the leader and say, are we having fun?

69
00:03:20.810 --> 00:03:25.450
Is it okay to crack some jokes, or
are we strictly business here with this?

70
00:03:25.450 --> 00:03:28.535
So, the leader kind of sets
the culture in how they act as well.

71
00:03:28.535 --> 00:03:30.920
>> Yeah, it's in the behavior
of everyone on the team.

72
00:03:30.920 --> 00:03:35.700
And culture in large part is defined
by what is accepted on the team, or

73
00:03:35.700 --> 00:03:37.920
what is punished on the team.

74
00:03:37.920 --> 00:03:41.010
And another reason they
call it leadership is

75
00:03:41.010 --> 00:03:44.810
people are going to follow the lead
of the head person on the team.

76
00:03:44.810 --> 00:03:49.920
They drive the culture a lot by what they
accept, what they punish, who they put

77
00:03:49.920 --> 00:03:54.640
in specific positions, who they reward,
based on their actions and behaviors.

78
00:03:54.640 --> 00:03:58.690
So, in a large part there, the leader
does set the standard for the culture.

79
00:03:58.690 --> 00:04:01.248
>> All right.
So, you mentioned you have some examples,

80
00:04:01.248 --> 00:04:02.950
so walk us through those.

81
00:04:02.950 --> 00:04:05.110
>> Well, Peter, I've got a couple of
examples I want to share with you.

82
00:04:05.110 --> 00:04:10.710
The first one is based on a research study
I did several years ago of 10,000 high

83
00:04:10.710 --> 00:04:13.450
potential employees at top
companies around the world.

84
00:04:13.450 --> 00:04:14.920
These are employees that are so

85
00:04:14.920 --> 00:04:17.830
good at what they do,
I call them voluntary employees.

86
00:04:17.830 --> 00:04:19.820
In other words, they've got options.

87
00:04:19.820 --> 00:04:23.710
If they decided at 10 o'clock, well
actually I have a young lady I work with

88
00:04:23.710 --> 00:04:28.700
at Microsoft that decided one day she
wasn't happy in her job, wasn't getting

89
00:04:28.700 --> 00:04:32.680
the career promotions she wanted to get,
and sort of let a head hunter, or

90
00:04:32.680 --> 00:04:36.360
two know about it and by the next day
she was a Vice President at Amazon.

91
00:04:36.360 --> 00:04:39.740
So, these are folks that go to work,
because they want to at this company not,

92
00:04:39.740 --> 00:04:40.770
because they have to.

93
00:04:40.770 --> 00:04:43.950
Because if they didn't like it they
could just get a job at the competition

94
00:04:43.950 --> 00:04:45.320
with in a day or two.

95
00:04:45.320 --> 00:04:48.590
So, when I asked them this question,
why do you work where you work.

96
00:04:48.590 --> 00:04:50.730
Because they could work
anywhere they wanted to work.

97
00:04:50.730 --> 00:04:52.420
Why did they choose to come
in to that they chose?

98
00:04:52.420 --> 00:04:54.340
And a lot of it was around culture.

99
00:04:54.340 --> 00:04:55.880
And there were six key things.

100
00:04:55.880 --> 00:04:58.680
And the first one is one that you may or

101
00:04:58.680 --> 00:05:02.460
may not have control of in your team,
which is fair pay.

102
00:05:02.460 --> 00:05:04.950
As long as they've got what they
call a reasonable pay, fair pay,

103
00:05:04.950 --> 00:05:06.335
they've got parity on pay,

104
00:05:06.335 --> 00:05:10.320
10% above or below what they would make
to do the same job any place else.

105
00:05:10.320 --> 00:05:12.770
Then pay came off
the table as a motivator.

106
00:05:12.770 --> 00:05:14.930
So, that maybe an organizational decision,

107
00:05:14.930 --> 00:05:19.140
or you might be able to impact
that somewhat as the team leader.

108
00:05:19.140 --> 00:05:22.230
The next thing they said,
is I wanna work with cool colleagues.

109
00:05:22.230 --> 00:05:25.730
I wanna work with a players, only want
to be on a team with other a players.

110
00:05:25.730 --> 00:05:28.960
And if you're going to build
a high performance team they want

111
00:05:28.960 --> 00:05:32.430
to be surrounded by other bright,
sharp, smart talented people

112
00:05:32.430 --> 00:05:36.140
that are good at what they do,
that are cool and highly competent.

113
00:05:36.140 --> 00:05:38.620
The next thing was challenging and
meaningful work.

114
00:05:38.620 --> 00:05:41.890
I want to come in everyday, and
feel like I'm using my full brain power.

115
00:05:41.890 --> 00:05:45.850
I'm dong things that are fun and
interesting, and engaging, and

116
00:05:45.850 --> 00:05:50.250
exciting, challenging me to be smarter,
to be innovative, to be creative,

117
00:05:50.250 --> 00:05:52.710
to improve my expertise.

118
00:05:52.710 --> 00:05:55.060
The next one was winning culture, and

119
00:05:55.060 --> 00:05:57.970
that's what we're going to talk about
in even more detail in just a second.

120
00:05:57.970 --> 00:06:01.640
But they want to be someplace where
it's got a strong supportive culture.

121
00:06:01.640 --> 00:06:04.190
The last two were really
fascinating to me.

122
00:06:04.190 --> 00:06:07.150
The next one is personal and
professional growth.

123
00:06:07.150 --> 00:06:10.020
What they said to me is I want to know

124
00:06:10.020 --> 00:06:12.680
that at the end of the month I'm
smarter than I was at the beginning.

125
00:06:12.680 --> 00:06:18.480
That my company is investing in mentors,
and coaches, and training, and support,

126
00:06:18.480 --> 00:06:21.800
and giving me opportunities to grow, and
get better, and better at what I do.

127
00:06:21.800 --> 00:06:25.460
That I'm constantly improving my
professional skills, personal improvement.

128
00:06:25.460 --> 00:06:27.930
The other thing was professional growth.

129
00:06:27.930 --> 00:06:32.300
And that says, can I look up in this
company, in this team, and see a place for

130
00:06:32.300 --> 00:06:35.180
me three, four, five,
ten years from today?

131
00:06:35.180 --> 00:06:38.380
If a really talented person feels like
they're not learning anything new,

132
00:06:38.380 --> 00:06:40.900
they're not improving, and
they can't see a place for

133
00:06:40.900 --> 00:06:46.100
themselves in the organization a few years
out, they will leave us fast as they can.

134
00:06:46.100 --> 00:06:48.700
And then the last one,
which is actually the most important one,

135
00:06:48.700 --> 00:06:51.835
Peter, was I worked for
a leader, I respect and admire.

136
00:06:51.835 --> 00:06:54.270
88% of people are quit their job.
