I do it because I care about you.

364
00:17:29.300 --> 00:17:32.420
I'm extremely talented, I'm trying to get
better everyday, I'm studying, learning,

365
00:17:32.420 --> 00:17:33.370
I'm working.

366
00:17:33.370 --> 00:17:36.020
And I do it all because I care about
the rest of the people on the team, and

367
00:17:36.020 --> 00:17:37.040
I want the team to succeed.

368
00:17:37.040 --> 00:17:38.260
>> All right, that makes sense.

369
00:17:38.260 --> 00:17:40.890
Now, John,
we've spent the first 20 minutes or so

370
00:17:40.890 --> 00:17:44.200
of this episode talking about how to
build a great culture on your team.

371
00:17:44.200 --> 00:17:47.230
But I bet you can destroy
a great culture pretty quickly.

372
00:17:47.230 --> 00:17:49.590
So, what are some of thing
we wanna make sure we avoid?

373
00:17:49.590 --> 00:17:51.200
What is it that can kill a culture?

374
00:17:51.200 --> 00:17:54.823
>> Yeah, w ell, this is, I'm gonna
share with you another good colleague,

375
00:17:54.823 --> 00:17:55.640
friend of mine.

376
00:17:55.640 --> 00:17:59.050
Patrick Lencioni wrote a great book
called The Five Dysfunctions of a Team.

377
00:17:59.050 --> 00:18:03.750
And this is probably the most famous
framework around dysfunctional teams.

378
00:18:03.750 --> 00:18:06.590
And there's five layers to it, and
he sorta describes it in a pyramid,

379
00:18:06.590 --> 00:18:08.140
from a base that goes up.

380
00:18:08.140 --> 00:18:12.400
So, the base of the pyramid is lack
of trust, what we just talked about.

381
00:18:12.400 --> 00:18:15.318
And the hard thing about trust,
I mentioned it briefly earlier,

382
00:18:15.318 --> 00:18:18.820
is it takes weeks, months, or
years to build up and seconds to lose.

383
00:18:18.820 --> 00:18:23.550
So that building that foundation of
strong trust on a team is essential.

384
00:18:23.550 --> 00:18:26.760
So a dysfunctional team
has a lack of that trust.

385
00:18:26.760 --> 00:18:28.690
The next one is lack of candor.

386
00:18:28.690 --> 00:18:30.970
Another word I like to use
there is vulnerability.

387
00:18:30.970 --> 00:18:34.040
Because I don't really trust the other
people on the team too much,

388
00:18:34.040 --> 00:18:37.320
I'm afraid to be vulnerable or
to speak my mind or

389
00:18:37.320 --> 00:18:41.630
to challenge someone else's idea
because I don't want retribution.

390
00:18:41.630 --> 00:18:45.066
And I don't want to share my ideas,
cuz I don't want to look stupid.

391
00:18:45.066 --> 00:18:49.380
So I sit in a meeting and things come up
that I'm concerned about with the team,

392
00:18:49.380 --> 00:18:52.670
but because I don't really trust
everybody else, I don't say anything.

393
00:18:52.670 --> 00:18:55.870
Which leads to the third one,
which is lack of commitment.

394
00:18:55.870 --> 00:18:59.060
We're in the meeting, we're talking,
I don't have a high enough level of trust.

395
00:18:59.060 --> 00:19:00.600
I'm not really sharing my ideas.

396
00:19:00.600 --> 00:19:03.950
I'm not being open, and
honest, and vulnerable.

397
00:19:03.950 --> 00:19:07.790
And the team wants to commit to something
that I think is the stupidest idea

398
00:19:07.790 --> 00:19:09.450
I've ever heard of in my life.

399
00:19:09.450 --> 00:19:12.400
And then they go around the table and they
go, what do you think about that, Peter?

400
00:19:12.400 --> 00:19:13.100
And Peter goes, I love it!

401
00:19:13.100 --> 00:19:14.570
What do you think about that, Taylor?

402
00:19:14.570 --> 00:19:16.710
What do you think about that, Megan?

403
00:19:16.710 --> 00:19:17.400
It's fantastic!

404
00:19:17.400 --> 00:19:18.990
They get to you and they go,
what do you think, John?

405
00:19:18.990 --> 00:19:23.240
And you go, love it, love it,
great, great, great!

406
00:19:23.240 --> 00:19:24.400
Love that!
And then what happens?

407
00:19:24.400 --> 00:19:27.130
Do you have the meeting after the meeting
where you go out to the parking lot and

408
00:19:27.130 --> 00:19:30.740
you're talking to one of your, that's the
stupidest idea I've ever heard in my life!

409
00:19:30.740 --> 00:19:33.900
So we've got lack of trust
leads to lack of candor or

410
00:19:33.900 --> 00:19:36.670
vulnerability, which leads
to lack of commitment.

411
00:19:36.670 --> 00:19:38.150
>> And
I remember you said something earlier,

412
00:19:38.150 --> 00:19:41.700
that you can attack ideas
without attacking people.

413
00:19:41.700 --> 00:19:44.380
So, that would be a great opportunity
to do that, in that example.

414
00:19:44.380 --> 00:19:47.782
>> Yeah, that and, but
without that lack of trust and candor,

415
00:19:47.782 --> 00:19:49.620
people are afraid to do that.

416
00:19:49.620 --> 00:19:52.680
So they sit in there and they commit
to things they don't believe in.

417
00:19:52.680 --> 00:19:56.960
A highly functional team, when somebody
put an idea out that the rest of the team

418
00:19:56.960 --> 00:20:00.770
did not agree with, they would be very
polite and respectful to the person, but

419
00:20:00.770 --> 00:20:03.880
they would attack the idea and
say this is what I don't like about it,

420
00:20:03.880 --> 00:20:06.520
here's how we can make it better,
this is how we can change it.

421
00:20:06.520 --> 00:20:09.310
But if it's a sub-functional team,
they don't say that.

422
00:20:09.310 --> 00:20:12.080
So what happens then,
the next one is lack of accountability.

423
00:20:12.080 --> 00:20:16.380
Is I don't trust the team or the rest of
the people, I'm not communicating with

424
00:20:16.380 --> 00:20:20.150
candor, I've made a commitment
I'm not really committed to, so

425
00:20:20.150 --> 00:20:21.650
I don't wanna be held accountable for it.

426
00:20:21.650 --> 00:20:24.850
I think it's a stupid idea, and I'm not
gonna point the finger of accountability

427
00:20:24.850 --> 00:20:27.040
at you, Peter,
cuz you're just gonna point it back at me.

428
00:20:27.040 --> 00:20:30.070
Because I don't wanna be held accountable,
I'm not gonna hold you accountable.

429
00:20:30.070 --> 00:20:31.160
Which leads to the fifth and

430
00:20:31.160 --> 00:20:34.620
final dysfunction of the team
which is lack of results.

431
00:20:34.620 --> 00:20:38.300
If nobody's holding each other
accountable, and we've said this multiple

432
00:20:38.300 --> 00:20:42.037
times during these episodes, is one of
the major factors you've gotta have in

433
00:20:42.037 --> 00:20:45.623
high performance team is high levels
of personal mutual accountability.

434
00:20:45.623 --> 00:20:48.900
Without that accountability,
you can't deliver results.

435
00:20:48.900 --> 00:20:51.780
>> So what I took away from that
is there's a lot of steps and

436
00:20:51.780 --> 00:20:53.730
it's difficult to build a team.

437
00:20:53.730 --> 00:20:56.590
It's pretty easy to go ahead and
break one down, it sounds like.

438
00:20:56.590 --> 00:21:01.230
And one or two little mistakes can
kind of have some big consequences.

439
00:21:01.230 --> 00:21:03.550
So, how do we hold it all together?

440
00:21:03.550 --> 00:21:05.270
>> There's multiple ways
to hold this together.

441
00:21:05.270 --> 00:21:06.560
First of all, the leader has to be,

442
00:21:06.560 --> 00:21:11.080
as you mentioned earlier, a living example
of what the culture of the team is.

443
00:21:11.080 --> 00:21:15.480
And the other big thing is to
reinforce positive behaviors

444
00:21:15.480 --> 00:21:19.950
with positive reinforcement, and negative
behaviors with negative reinforcement.

445
00:21:19.950 --> 00:21:23.610
In other words, if someone's doing
something that doesn't match the culture,

446
00:21:23.610 --> 00:21:26.310
they've got be held accountable for
that, you gotta call them out and

447
00:21:26.310 --> 00:21:28.670
get them back into the norm of the team.

448
00:21:28.670 --> 00:21:33.320
When someone is really living the team
culture, you want to give them awards,

449
00:21:33.320 --> 00:21:34.900
pat them on the back, and

450
00:21:34.900 --> 00:21:38.710
make sure they understand that you
are doing exactly what we all agreed to.

451
00:21:38.710 --> 00:21:43.230
Another big factor in this is doing things
away from working in the company together.

452
00:21:43.230 --> 00:21:46.010
Going out for beer,
going bowling, or going out and

453
00:21:46.010 --> 00:21:50.420
getting a pizza, so that that culture gets
ingrained and we build that friendship and

454
00:21:50.420 --> 00:21:52.120
that camaraderie and trust.

455
00:21:52.120 --> 00:21:52.970
Because a big,

456
00:21:52.970 --> 00:21:56.600
big foundation of trust is also how
well do I know the folks on my team.

457
00:21:56.600 --> 00:22:00.220
If I only work with them at the office,
I never see them outside of the office,

458
00:22:00.220 --> 00:22:04.400
then it's hard for
me to build up a personal trust with them,

459
00:22:04.400 --> 00:22:07.250
what we call tie strength,
where we are friendly and

460
00:22:07.250 --> 00:22:09.830
we get to know each other more
than just the work we're doing.

461
00:22:09.830 --> 00:22:12.990
So those are some of the elements it
takes to hold a culture together, but

462
00:22:12.990 --> 00:22:14.810
this isn't done by chance.

463
00:22:14.810 --> 00:22:19.390
It's done because you purposely work on
the culture, make sure it's going well,

464
00:22:19.390 --> 00:22:22.450
strongly support it,
make sure that no one's breaking it down.

465
00:22:22.450 --> 00:22:24.680
And talk about it often, and

466
00:22:24.680 --> 00:22:27.940
make sure that the culture's where
everybody wants it to be, and that it's

467
00:22:27.940 --> 00:22:31.300
engaging, exciting, the people are having
fun and they like working on the team.

468
00:22:31.300 --> 00:22:34.870
>> Yes, so maybe a culture does grow
organically, but it takes work and

469
00:22:34.870 --> 00:22:36.690
it takes effort to maintain it and

470
00:22:36.690 --> 00:22:39.720
make sure you keep that up as
the company grows, as it gets bigger,

471
00:22:39.720 --> 00:22:42.520
as you add more people, bringing
all those people into that culture.

472
00:22:42.520 --> 00:22:45.660
So John, we're pretty close on time for
this episode.

473
00:22:45.660 --> 00:22:47.130
Any final thoughts?

474
00:22:47.130 --> 00:22:51.430
>> My final thought would be that
culture can make or break your team.

475
00:22:51.430 --> 00:22:54.734
You can have the most talented people,
you can have a clear objective,

476
00:22:54.734 --> 00:22:58.110
you can have a strong sponsor,
you can the resources, the technology.

477
00:22:58.110 --> 00:23:02.400
You could have everything you need, but if
you don't create a culture of coherence,

478
00:23:02.400 --> 00:23:05.860
of alignment, where people like each
other, and they wanna work together, and

479
00:23:05.860 --> 00:23:07.620
they're excited to be there every day,

480
00:23:07.620 --> 00:23:10.810
without that culture it's impossible
to have an effective team.

481
00:23:10.810 --> 00:23:12.590
>> Sounds good.
There's a lot of great information there

482
00:23:12.590 --> 00:23:15.700
you can probably implement
right away in your business and

483
00:23:15.700 --> 00:23:19.300
help improve your culture as
you're leading your tech teams.

484
00:23:19.300 --> 00:23:22.330
And we have a lot more great
information coming up in other episodes

485
00:23:22.330 --> 00:23:23.700
about leading those tech teams.

486
00:23:23.700 --> 00:23:25.810
But for now,
we're gonna go ahead and sign off.

487
00:23:25.810 --> 00:23:27.230
I'm Peter VanRysdam.

488
00:23:27.230 --> 00:23:27.990
>> I'm John Spence.

489
00:23:27.990 --> 00:23:29.733
>> And we'll see you next time.

490
00:23:29.733 --> 00:23:39.733
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this section you will explore why having a highly engaged, loyal and committed team members is essential to success. You will look at how to build trust in an organization, on a personal level and as a team leader. You will also find out about how to overcome distrust and create a high level of commitment to the organization, to the team and as a team leader.
episodes.title: Building Trust and Commitment on Your Team
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:04.989
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:04.989 --> 00:00:06.942
Hello and welcome to BizProTV.

3
00:00:06.942 --> 00:00:08.691
I'm your host Peter VanRysdam and

4
00:00:08.691 --> 00:00:12.360
today continuing in our series
about building technology teams.

5
00:00:12.360 --> 00:00:16.230
And specifically in this episode we're
talking about building commitment and

6
00:00:16.230 --> 00:00:18.590
teamwork, and trust within those teams.

7
00:00:18.590 --> 00:00:21.020
Here to help us with that,
we have Mr. John Spence.

8
00:00:21.020 --> 00:00:21.750
John, how you doing?

9
00:00:21.750 --> 00:00:22.970
>> Doing wonderful, Peter, and you?

10
00:00:22.970 --> 00:00:24.210
>> I'm doing fantastic, thanks.

11
00:00:24.210 --> 00:00:24.950
>> Good, good.

12
00:00:24.950 --> 00:00:28.520
>> So, where do we start in
building trust on your team?

13
00:00:28.520 --> 00:00:31.720
>> Well, before we talk about and
commitment, let me talk about

14
00:00:31.720 --> 00:00:36.050
why the lack of trust and
commitment is so incredibly challenging.

15
00:00:37.060 --> 00:00:41.258
Right now, statistics
are somewhere between about 60 and

16
00:00:41.258 --> 00:00:44.335
77% of employees are disengaged or
not committed.

17
00:00:44.335 --> 00:00:47.490
You've got your disengaged
employees that really just don't

18
00:00:47.490 --> 00:00:49.880
care that much about the company.

19
00:00:49.880 --> 00:00:52.690
They don't really like what they do, and
they don't really like the organization

20
00:00:52.690 --> 00:00:55.360
they work in, but
they show up every day anyways.

21
00:00:55.360 --> 00:00:58.510
There is also a portion that
are called actively disengaged,

22
00:00:58.510 --> 00:01:02.950
which are actively attempting
to sabotage the organization.

23
00:01:02.950 --> 00:01:05.700
The analogy I like to use is if
you've got a good team on a boat,

24
00:01:05.700 --> 00:01:07.730
you're all rowing in the same direction.

25
00:01:07.730 --> 00:01:11.770
If you have a somewhat dysfunctional
team with disengaged people,

26
00:01:11.770 --> 00:01:15.910
most of the boat's rowing in one way and
somebody's either dragging their oars or

27
00:01:15.910 --> 00:01:17.470
they're rowing against it.

28
00:01:17.470 --> 00:01:19.820
But when you've got
actively disengaged people,

29
00:01:19.820 --> 00:01:22.910
they're basically filling buckets of
water and putting it in the boat or

30
00:01:22.910 --> 00:01:25.150
drilling wholes in
the boat as you go along.

31
00:01:25.150 --> 00:01:27.450
Now we're making light of it but

32
00:01:27.450 --> 00:01:31.560
the truth of the matter is,
it's exceedingly expensive to companies.

33
00:01:31.560 --> 00:01:33.820
Larger companies lose
hundreds of millions or

34
00:01:33.820 --> 00:01:37.670
billions of dollars from team
members that are not committed.

35
00:01:37.670 --> 00:01:41.050
It can put a small business
out of business and

36
00:01:41.050 --> 00:01:44.340
it can really hurt your career
if your not a good team player.

37
00:01:44.340 --> 00:01:46.940
So, what I'd like to do is although we
talked about it in one of the other

38
00:01:46.940 --> 00:01:49.110
sessions, I'd like to go back and

39
00:01:49.110 --> 00:01:54.920
quickly refresh on Patrick Lencioni's idea
around the five dysfunctions of a team.

40
00:01:54.920 --> 00:01:59.110
I was actually talking to a senior
professor at a major university yesterday

41
00:01:59.110 --> 00:02:02.140
about this, and we came up with
a few new ideas to add into it.

42
00:02:02.140 --> 00:02:05.810
So there are five things that ruin a team.

43
00:02:05.810 --> 00:02:09.310
At the base of it, and the thing that
really causes the most trouble, and

44
00:02:09.310 --> 00:02:12.520
exactly why we're doing this session,
is lack of trust.

45
00:02:12.520 --> 00:02:15.510
And we're going to talk quite a bit about
how to build trust, how to overcome

46
00:02:15.510 --> 00:02:22.040
distrust in the next few minutes, but
just understand that the single most

47
00:02:22.040 --> 00:02:26.850
devastating thing to a team is when the
team members don't truly trust themselves.

48
00:02:26.850 --> 00:02:31.290
That lack of trust then leads to a lack
of candor or a lack of vulnerability.

49
00:02:31.290 --> 00:02:33.110
And here's the new word we
came up with yesterday.

50
00:02:33.110 --> 00:02:34.990
It's really a lack of transparency.

51
00:02:34.990 --> 00:02:38.070
People hoarding knowledge,
not sharing information.

52
00:02:38.070 --> 00:02:40.290
Not saying everything
that's on their mind.

53
00:02:40.290 --> 00:02:42.020
So when you don't really trust each other,

54
00:02:42.020 --> 00:02:46.630
you don't have the good open, honest,
robust transparent communication

55
00:02:46.630 --> 00:02:49.580
that is essential to having
a high performing team.

56
00:02:49.580 --> 00:02:52.710
At the next level then is we
have a lack of commitment.

57
00:02:52.710 --> 00:02:56.700
He and I, yesterday, were talking about
a project in China we're both working on.

58
00:02:56.700 --> 00:02:59.400
And I said, it's sort of like you're
all sitting around the table and

59
00:02:59.400 --> 00:03:02.140
someone's going, hey, what do you
think about the China projects?

60
00:03:02.140 --> 00:03:05.140
Somebody goes it's fantastic, love it,
can't wait to get over there.

61
00:03:05.140 --> 00:03:06.570
Shanghai's gonna be awesome.

62
00:03:06.570 --> 00:03:09.120
And the next person at the table goes,
I've been to China three or

63
00:03:09.120 --> 00:03:11.320
four times, love that place, fantastic.

64
00:03:11.320 --> 00:03:14.650
Then they point at you and
you're thinking, this is a disaster.

65
00:03:14.650 --> 00:03:15.700
We're gonna lose money.

66
00:03:15.700 --> 00:03:18.090
This is a really bad idea.

67
00:03:18.090 --> 00:03:21.670
But because you don't have a high level of
trust with everybody else at the table,

68
00:03:21.670 --> 00:03:23.380
you're not willing to be vulnerable.

69
00:03:23.380 --> 00:03:26.690
You don't wanna speak courageously or
you're afraid to be transparent and

70
00:03:26.690 --> 00:03:27.720
share your feelings.

71
00:03:27.720 --> 00:03:30.730
So you go excited about China too,
they're gonna be great.

72
00:03:32.100 --> 00:03:35.550
What happens then there in the next
level is lack of accountability.

73
00:03:35.550 --> 00:03:38.980
I have agreed to something
I don't believe in.

74
00:03:38.980 --> 00:03:42.010
Or someone else on the team has agreed
to something they don't believe in

75
00:03:42.010 --> 00:03:45.200
cuz we didn't have enough trust and
we weren't transparent and

76
00:03:45.200 --> 00:03:47.410
we made commitments that
we didn't believe in.

77
00:03:47.410 --> 00:03:48.890
Now I don't wanna be held accountable for

78
00:03:48.890 --> 00:03:50.880
the commitments cuz I
don't believe in them.

79
00:03:50.880 --> 00:03:54.990
And I'm not gonna hold you accountable cuz
you're just gonna hold me accountable and

80
00:03:54.990 --> 00:03:57.640
we all don't want that,
which leads to the fifth and

81
00:03:57.640 --> 00:04:00.570
final dysfunction is lack of results.

82
00:04:00.570 --> 00:04:03.321
So before we talk about trust and
commitment,

83
00:04:03.321 --> 00:04:06.493
I wanted to help you understand
that a lack of trust and

84
00:04:06.493 --> 00:04:11.520
commitment is extremely expensive not only
to the organization but to your career.

85
00:04:11.520 --> 00:04:13.539
And without trust, you don't have candor,

86
00:04:13.539 --> 00:04:16.675
without candor you don't get real
commitment, no real commitment,

87
00:04:16.675 --> 00:04:20.750
there's no accountability and no results,
and that does not help the team, Peter.

88
00:04:20.750 --> 00:04:22.500
>> So John, what to we do about this?

89
00:04:22.500 --> 00:04:25.500
How do we go about building
trust within our organization?

90
00:04:25.500 --> 00:04:28.480
>> Okay, at an organizational level,
it's pretty simple.

91
00:04:28.480 --> 00:04:30.219
There are three major ideas.

92
00:04:31.530 --> 00:04:34.600
And a friend of mine who's a psychologist,
we were chatting about this, and

93
00:04:34.600 --> 00:04:38.820
he said, basically these are the exact
same three things that anybody needs in

94
00:04:38.820 --> 00:04:42.100
any important relationship,
with their spouse, with their friends,

95
00:04:42.100 --> 00:04:44.360
with their family, and your job.

96
00:04:44.360 --> 00:04:48.310
Because you [LAUGH] spend an awful lot of
time at work with the people you're there.

97
00:04:48.310 --> 00:04:49.460
It's a major part of your life.

98
00:04:49.460 --> 00:04:53.200
Your job is one of the biggest
relationships you have in your life.

99
00:04:53.200 --> 00:04:56.740
So the three things are, and
they're also on three levels.

100
00:04:56.740 --> 00:04:59.270
The first one is safety, safety.

101
00:04:59.270 --> 00:05:02.120
If you're going to be
committed to your company and

102
00:05:02.120 --> 00:05:04.040
feel trustworthy, you have to feel safe.

103
00:05:04.040 --> 00:05:06.720
And you have to feel safe on three levels.

104
00:05:06.720 --> 00:05:08.860
First is the emotional level.

105
00:05:08.860 --> 00:05:13.500
I need to feel safe that I'm not going
to be yelled at or embarrassed or

106
00:05:13.500 --> 00:05:14.942
taken advantage of.

107
00:05:14.942 --> 00:05:18.476
Physical safety is, I'm not gonna
get a machine that grab my arms or

108
00:05:18.476 --> 00:05:21.638
I'm not going to get electrocuted or
it's safe for me to walk

109
00:05:21.638 --> 00:05:26.320
out in the parking lot in the evening when
it's late after I've finished my work.

110
00:05:26.320 --> 00:05:30.590
And then the last one is psychological
safety which says my ideas are safe,

111
00:05:30.590 --> 00:05:35.000
that I'm not gonna be
constantly given a hard time,

112
00:05:35.000 --> 00:05:37.470
made fun of, teased, my ideas shot down.

113
00:05:37.470 --> 00:05:42.540
So I need to emotionally feel safe
that I'm not gonna be yelled at,

114
00:05:42.540 --> 00:05:45.420
screamed at,
embarrassed in front of everybody.

115
00:05:45.420 --> 00:05:46.750
I need to be physically safe.

116
00:05:46.750 --> 00:05:47.880
I won't get hurt.

117
00:05:47.880 --> 00:05:51.620
I need to be psychologically safe,
it's safe to share my ideas.

118
00:05:51.620 --> 00:05:52.830
So safety's the first one.

119
00:05:52.830 --> 00:05:54.220
>> So safety that makes a lot of sense.

120
00:05:54.220 --> 00:05:57.050
I don't want to lose an arm
in a machine or something.

121
00:05:57.050 --> 00:05:59.540
But anything else that we
need to do to build trust?

122
00:05:59.540 --> 00:06:02.029
>> There's two more stages
at an organizational level.

123
00:06:03.050 --> 00:06:03.880
So we've got safety.

124
00:06:03.880 --> 00:06:06.050
The next one is belongingness.

125
00:06:06.050 --> 00:06:09.458
And what this says is I wanna
feel like I belong on the team,

126
00:06:09.458 --> 00:06:12.160
that people enjoy being around me.

127
00:06:12.160 --> 00:06:15.400
They feel like I'm a partner,
I'm one of the group.

128
00:06:15.400 --> 00:06:19.540
And basically for all humans, we wanna
feel like we're part of the tribe.

129
00:06:19.540 --> 00:06:22.670
Nobody wants to be standing alone,
off on the side and not connected.

130
00:06:22.670 --> 00:06:25.640
So belongingness is critical and

131
00:06:25.640 --> 00:06:27.980
it's also part of way to build
a deeper level of trust.

132
00:06:27.980 --> 00:06:32.120
If we know each other, we care about each
other, I know about your family, and

133
00:06:32.120 --> 00:06:35.190
you really feel like I'm happy to
see you when you come to work, and

134
00:06:35.190 --> 00:06:37.670
you belong on the team, key idea.

135
00:06:37.670 --> 00:06:41.590
The last one is appreciation and
I've been doing this for a long time and

136
00:06:41.590 --> 00:06:45.810
even I didn't realize how critical it
is to really show genuine, honest,

137
00:06:45.810 --> 00:06:49.490
sincere appreciation and
to celebrate when things go right.

138
00:06:49.490 --> 00:06:51.410
And that's also on three levels.

139
00:06:51.410 --> 00:06:53.320
It's emotional appreciation.

140
00:06:53.320 --> 00:06:55.550
I like your sense of humor,
Peter, [LAUGH] well, not so

141
00:06:55.550 --> 00:06:58.120
much, but we have fun together.

142
00:06:58.120 --> 00:06:59.330
We enjoy stuff.

143
00:06:59.330 --> 00:07:02.050
I appreciate the fact that
you're happy when you come in.

144
00:07:02.050 --> 00:07:04.880
You got a good attitude and
you're passionate.

145
00:07:04.880 --> 00:07:07.090
It's also physical appreciation.

146
00:07:07.090 --> 00:07:08.480
I appreciate the work you do.

147
00:07:08.480 --> 00:07:12.430
When you're sitting at your computer and
you're coding, when you bring in a report,

148
00:07:12.430 --> 00:07:17.340
when you come and make some sort of
a presentation of the rest of the team.

149
00:07:17.340 --> 00:07:19.160
I appreciate the actual work you do.

150
00:07:19.160 --> 00:07:22.230
And then the last one is
psychological appreciation.

151
00:07:22.230 --> 00:07:24.470
And what that says is I
appreciate your diversity.

152
00:07:24.470 --> 00:07:27.630
I appreciate the new and different and
innovative ideas you bring.

153
00:07:27.630 --> 00:07:30.230
I appreciate the fact that you have
had a different background and

154
00:07:30.230 --> 00:07:32.470
different experiences than
the rest of the team.

155
00:07:32.470 --> 00:07:36.310
And you're bringing that to the team and
intellectually helping us be

156
00:07:36.310 --> 00:07:39.600
a more robust and
a more successful team with better ideas.

157
00:07:39.600 --> 00:07:43.830
So, very essential to build
in an organization, safety,

158
00:07:43.830 --> 00:07:45.900
belongingness, and appreciation.

159
00:07:45.900 --> 00:07:48.630
>> Now you've mentioned a couple of
times that that's building trust

160
00:07:48.630 --> 00:07:49.920
within an organization.

161
00:07:49.920 --> 00:07:52.130
What other levels are there that
we want to building trust in?

162
00:07:52.130 --> 00:07:54.333
>> Well the next one is personal trust,

163
00:07:54.333 --> 00:07:58.029
and this is something I've been
teaching for a long time, and

164
00:07:58.029 --> 00:08:02.458
it's one of the very hardest concepts for
people to grasp in my sessions.

165
00:08:02.458 --> 00:08:06.592
And here's the idea Peter, and
this is a big one is, to build trust,

166
00:08:06.592 --> 00:08:08.390
you must extend trust first.

167
00:08:09.420 --> 00:08:11.540
In other words, and
here's the way I sort of explain it,

168
00:08:11.540 --> 00:08:15.600
when I meet most people, Megan,
I've met this girl Megan.

169
00:08:15.600 --> 00:08:18.010
She's very nice, but
I don't know her at all.

170
00:08:18.010 --> 00:08:22.108
And in that initial conversation, if I
were to see a little bubble of trust over

171
00:08:22.108 --> 00:08:26.347
her head, for most people, that bubble
starts at zero, on a scale of one to ten.

172
00:08:26.347 --> 00:08:29.382
I don't know her, I can't trust her,
I never been around her before,

173
00:08:29.382 --> 00:08:30.958
we have no background, no history.

174
00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:34.118
But I hang out with Megan for the day,
we do some work on a project,

175
00:08:34.118 --> 00:08:35.730
she seems pretty cool.

176
00:08:35.730 --> 00:08:38.680
Maybe it goes up to a two and
then I run into her another week or

177
00:08:38.680 --> 00:08:42.115
two later and we end up going to lunch and
talking about our families.

178
00:08:42.115 --> 00:08:43.682
And now it's up to a five or a six.

179
00:08:43.682 --> 00:08:47.249
And maybe six months later we run into
each other at a big convention or

180
00:08:47.249 --> 00:08:49.785
a conference we got out and
have a beer together.

181
00:08:49.785 --> 00:08:53.072
And now it's up to an eight nine, and
maybe the next year she finally gets to,

182
00:08:53.072 --> 00:08:55.640
we had two, two and
a half years of hanging out.

183
00:08:55.640 --> 00:08:58.800
Finally now,
Megan is a ten on my trust level.

184
00:08:58.800 --> 00:09:01.510
Problem, it took two years to get there.

185
00:09:01.510 --> 00:09:05.180
So here's the big challenging
thing is if you really want to

186
00:09:05.180 --> 00:09:09.180
build trust on your team, you need
to start at ten with other people.

187
00:09:09.180 --> 00:09:13.540
You need to extend full trust and
full respect at the very beginning.

188
00:09:13.540 --> 00:09:16.995
Now a lot of people say, but
they'll take advantage of me.

189
00:09:16.995 --> 00:09:18.415
That's being naive.

190
00:09:18.415 --> 00:09:21.140
I'm not saying they have to stay at a ten.

191
00:09:21.140 --> 00:09:23.420
If they do something to violate that,

192
00:09:23.420 --> 00:09:26.880
you can take it from a ten
to a zero immediately.

193
00:09:26.880 --> 00:09:30.130
But if you tell someone,
you've got to hang around with me.

194
00:09:30.130 --> 00:09:31.650
I've got to watch you do your work.

195
00:09:31.650 --> 00:09:35.307
I've got to do this for 18 months or
2 years before I decide to trust you,

196
00:09:35.307 --> 00:09:36.946
then I'm finally comfortable.

197
00:09:36.946 --> 00:09:39.650
That's very, very hard to
build a high performance team,

198
00:09:39.650 --> 00:09:42.960
especially if you're only gonna
be together for a few months.

199
00:09:42.960 --> 00:09:46.930
So big challenges,
how do you extend full trust and

200
00:09:46.930 --> 00:09:52.040
full respect first, and then only take
it away if the other person violates it?

201
00:09:52.040 --> 00:09:55.770
And if you can come together as a team and
agree on that idea,

202
00:09:55.770 --> 00:10:01.120
you can catapult past other teams, by
beginning with a very high level of trust.

203
00:10:01.120 --> 00:10:02.900
>> And
maybe you get burned one out of ten times,

204
00:10:02.900 --> 00:10:06.110
but you're able to be that much
more productive right off the bat,

205
00:10:06.110 --> 00:10:09.170
which sounds like it's
potentially worth that risk.

206
00:10:09.170 --> 00:10:11.363
So that's building trust
as an individual then.

207
00:10:11.363 --> 00:10:13.300
Any more?

208
00:10:13.300 --> 00:10:15.800
>> Okay, so we've got as an organization,

209
00:10:15.800 --> 00:10:19.260
we've got it individually which is
also sort of intermixed in the team.

210
00:10:19.260 --> 00:10:22.367
And now I'd like to go to slide and talk
about how to do this as a team leader.

211
00:10:22.367 --> 00:10:25.080
How do you build trust as a team leader?

212
00:10:25.080 --> 00:10:26.510
So here we're gonna go through this.

213
00:10:26.510 --> 00:10:29.010
And this is now when
you're leading the team or

214
00:10:29.010 --> 00:10:33.440
you stepped into a role of leading the
team for a while on part of the project.

215
00:10:33.440 --> 00:10:36.930
First and most important is to
establish and maintain integrity.

216
00:10:38.200 --> 00:10:40.980
And I've mentioned this before,
but again, it's worth saying.

217
00:10:40.980 --> 00:10:45.350
A couple of times, actually, multiple
times, the single most important thing

218
00:10:45.350 --> 00:10:50.280
that people look for in a leader they
would willingly follow, is honesty.

219
00:10:50.280 --> 00:10:55.140
In a global survey,
90% of people on the face

220
00:10:55.140 --> 00:10:58.440
of the earth said that if
my leader isn't honest,

221
00:10:58.440 --> 00:11:01.450
there's no way that I will trust him and
there's no way that I'll follow him.

222
00:11:01.450 --> 00:11:05.666
So you've got to constantly show that
you are in integrity with your values.

223
00:11:05.666 --> 00:11:10.261
Which brings me to another point is, if
you're gonna be a leader you need to share

224
00:11:10.261 --> 00:11:13.130
with your team your leadership philosophy.

225
00:11:13.130 --> 00:11:17.652
The core values you plan to lead the team
by, honesty, integrity, fairness,

226
00:11:17.652 --> 00:11:19.688
respect, passion, commitment.

227
00:11:19.688 --> 00:11:23.390
I don't know what they are, but
you need to think those through.

228
00:11:23.390 --> 00:11:26.774
Because the only way that someone
can measure if you have integrity

229
00:11:26.774 --> 00:11:30.530
is to understand what values you're
holding your integrity up against.

230
00:11:30.530 --> 00:11:35.013
The next thing is, and this is one
of the big issues we see over and

231
00:11:35.013 --> 00:11:39.510
over again is not communicating
division well enough.

232
00:11:39.510 --> 00:11:43.120
So in an organization, on the whole,
this is a huge problem.

233
00:11:43.120 --> 00:11:47.313
On a team what the team leader needs to
do is constantly talk about the vision,

234
00:11:47.313 --> 00:11:51.569
the direction, the purpose of the team,
to keep people aligned on the team and

235
00:11:51.569 --> 00:11:52.555
moving forward.

236
00:11:52.555 --> 00:11:54.738
And the reason this is
important to trust is,

237
00:11:54.738 --> 00:11:57.100
if I tell everybody we're
going in direction a.

238
00:11:57.100 --> 00:11:58.293
We're going to go in a, in a.

239
00:11:58.293 --> 00:11:59.828
And then all of a sudden I go, no,
we're headed in b and we're going to go b.

240
00:11:59.828 --> 00:12:01.599
No, no, now we're headed c.

241
00:12:01.599 --> 00:12:06.470
That inconsistency of vision and
direction destroys trust.

242
00:12:06.470 --> 00:12:09.390
The next thing we're gonna look
at is making sure that you treat

243
00:12:09.390 --> 00:12:11.180
everybody on the team as an equal.

244
00:12:12.250 --> 00:12:16.240
It is very hard to trust your team leader
if you think they have special people on

245
00:12:16.240 --> 00:12:18.080
the team that they're looking out for.

246
00:12:18.080 --> 00:12:19.840
That they give more opportunity to or

247
00:12:19.840 --> 00:12:22.519
they give them a break if
they don't turn something in.

248
00:12:22.519 --> 00:12:25.680
The team, the leader's pet.

249
00:12:25.680 --> 00:12:29.590
You don't trust a leader who
treats people differently.

250
00:12:29.590 --> 00:12:32.320
Now I'm not saying that they might
challenge somebody who's got a higher

251
00:12:32.320 --> 00:12:34.269
level of skills a little
harder than somebody else.

252
00:12:34.269 --> 00:12:37.841
What I'm talking about is fairness,
rules, and

253
00:12:37.841 --> 00:12:43.029
respect that everyone on the team gets
treated the same way around time,

254
00:12:43.029 --> 00:12:46.420
flexibility, exposure, things like that.

255
00:12:46.420 --> 00:12:48.990
Things that people want on a team
to allow them to be successful.

256
00:12:48.990 --> 00:12:51.621
That the team leader isn't making
a couple of people their little pets, and

257
00:12:51.621 --> 00:12:52.410
making them special.

258
00:12:54.460 --> 00:12:58.250
This is a big one that
the team leader has to model.

259
00:12:58.250 --> 00:13:01.748
Which is, we are all on the same team and
we have a shared goal,

260
00:13:01.748 --> 00:13:07.610
a shared outcome, and a shared reward
to all of us doing this together.

261
00:13:07.610 --> 00:13:11.439
Once you start getting fractions on a team
and things get siloed you will not have

262
00:13:11.439 --> 00:13:15.225
trust or commitment on the team because
it becomes everybody for themselves.

263
00:13:15.225 --> 00:13:19.293
So it's essential that the team
leader constantly be showing people,

264
00:13:19.293 --> 00:13:21.080
we're all in this together.

265
00:13:21.080 --> 00:13:21.825
We're on the same team.

266
00:13:21.825 --> 00:13:23.760
We're moving forward together.

267
00:13:23.760 --> 00:13:26.930
We've got a shared direction,
shared goals, a shared outcome, and

268
00:13:26.930 --> 00:13:29.150
we will all share in the success.

269
00:13:29.150 --> 00:13:32.380
And then the last thing
is that as a leader,

270
00:13:32.380 --> 00:13:35.840
if you really wanna build
trust strong on your team,

271
00:13:35.840 --> 00:13:40.770
you've gotta do what's right for the team
and the organization above yourself.

272
00:13:40.770 --> 00:13:44.049
There's a word we use for
this in leadership, servant leadership,

273
00:13:44.049 --> 00:13:48.022
where you say it's my job to support the
team and make sure the team's successful.

274
00:13:48.022 --> 00:13:51.693
Even if it might be challenging or
difficult for my career, or

275
00:13:51.693 --> 00:13:56.634
even risking my career, but I'm willing to
put a stake in the ground and stand up for

276
00:13:56.634 --> 00:14:01.752
my team even if it might cost me personal
difficulties, and challenges, and risks.

277
00:14:01.752 --> 00:14:05.050
>> All right so John, you mentioned it's
good to kind of start with that level of

278
00:14:05.050 --> 00:14:08.030
trust and
you then you can build on that or

279
00:14:08.030 --> 00:14:10.380
it can be taken away from
if something goes wrong.

280
00:14:10.380 --> 00:14:15.256
But how do we overcome distrust if
that does come up within our team?

281
00:14:15.256 --> 00:14:19.354
>> Okay, Peter, so we've worked hard,
we've tried to make the team work great

282
00:14:19.354 --> 00:14:23.718
and now something's gotten in there and
we're starting to spiral into distrust.

283
00:14:23.718 --> 00:14:28.355
And this is one of those things they call
it the, Jim Collins in his book calls it

284
00:14:28.355 --> 00:14:32.292
the fly wheel in the doom loop It's
hard to get the fly wheel going,

285
00:14:32.292 --> 00:14:35.350
it's like pushing a car down the road.

286
00:14:35.350 --> 00:14:37.835
If you stop for
a second it slows down immediately, but

287
00:14:37.835 --> 00:14:41.254
once you get a little momentum going
you can keep push car it's not as hard.

288
00:14:41.254 --> 00:14:44.910
But the minute you stop or start to go
uphill it just rolls back over you.

289
00:14:44.910 --> 00:14:47.030
So same thing with a team.

290
00:14:47.030 --> 00:14:49.958
If you've got a pretty high level
of trust, you're doing well and

291
00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:52.259
something comes in and
violates the trust on a team,

292
00:14:52.259 --> 00:14:54.682
you're gonna start to see
a wave of distrusts coming.

293
00:14:54.682 --> 00:14:57.480
And there's a couple of
things you need to do.

294
00:14:57.480 --> 00:14:59.630
Number one is admit that
you have a problem.

295
00:14:59.630 --> 00:15:02.860
A lot of times on teams,
people just hope it'll go away.

296
00:15:02.860 --> 00:15:04.870
If I just don't say anything and

297
00:15:04.870 --> 00:15:07.380
I just try to be a little
extra nice to this person.

298
00:15:07.380 --> 00:15:11.910
Or I don't bring up this issue or this
challenge maybe we can just pretend that

299
00:15:11.910 --> 00:15:16.280
people aren't arguing, and
fighting, and backstabbing.

300
00:15:16.280 --> 00:15:18.530
So the first one is and
let's go ahead and look at the slide,

301
00:15:18.530 --> 00:15:21.880
I've got a couple more here
that I want to put up.

302
00:15:21.880 --> 00:15:26.270
Once you've understood that there is
a problem and you've faced up to it and

303
00:15:26.270 --> 00:15:27.370
you know you have to deal with it,

304
00:15:28.410 --> 00:15:32.430
the most important thing next step is
to ask people about their stories.

305
00:15:32.430 --> 00:15:34.810
What happened?
Why do you feel this way?

306
00:15:34.810 --> 00:15:37.250
What did the other person say, or do, or

307
00:15:37.250 --> 00:15:42.200
what was the situation that began to
erode your trust in other person?

308
00:15:42.200 --> 00:15:45.390
And I have seen teams,
worked with one not so long ago,

309
00:15:45.390 --> 00:15:50.076
where there were two ladies on the team
who, for years, didn't get along.

310
00:15:50.076 --> 00:15:52.795
And this was a senior management team,
and it made the team very dysfunctional.

311
00:15:52.795 --> 00:15:55.446
They didn't like to sit next
to each other in meetings.

312
00:15:55.446 --> 00:15:58.465
They didn't support each other
when they came up with ideas.

313
00:15:58.465 --> 00:16:03.504
And it turns out that three years ago,
one of the women had said something

314
00:16:03.504 --> 00:16:08.700
about the other woman's husband
in a not so complementary way.

315
00:16:08.700 --> 00:16:11.420
And she took that as a personal insult and
for

316
00:16:11.420 --> 00:16:15.990
three years, she didn't wanna work well
with this other woman on the team.

317
00:16:15.990 --> 00:16:17.800
And when I sat down
separately with them and

318
00:16:17.800 --> 00:16:21.070
said tell me what's going on here,
tell me your story.

319
00:16:21.070 --> 00:16:25.720
The story came out and the other
women who had made the insult said,

320
