542
00:28:24.290 --> 00:28:27.130
I was jumping down and
I want to go back up.

543
00:28:27.130 --> 00:28:29.540
We said it earlier, but
I forgot to put it in here.

544
00:28:29.540 --> 00:28:31.612
The single most important
thing is honesty.

545
00:28:31.612 --> 00:28:33.010
We said that back with trust.

546
00:28:33.010 --> 00:28:35.417
Where there's no trust,
where there's no honesty there's no trust,

547
00:28:35.417 --> 00:28:37.530
where there's no trust
there's no commitment.

548
00:28:37.530 --> 00:28:39.130
If you're gonna lead
a team effectively and

549
00:28:39.130 --> 00:28:41.180
get them committed they have to
know you're telling the truth.

550
00:28:41.180 --> 00:28:44.190
>> I'm gonna take it as an honest mistake
and you did not lost my trust yet.

551
00:28:44.190 --> 00:28:45.240
>> [LAUGH]
>> So please go ahead.

552
00:28:45.240 --> 00:28:46.290
>> Thank you, I appreciate it.

553
00:28:46.290 --> 00:28:47.810
So we've got, you're honest,

554
00:28:47.810 --> 00:28:52.270
you're forward looking visionary, you're
competent and the next one is inspiring.

555
00:28:52.270 --> 00:28:54.100
And I can phrase this up real quick.

556
00:28:54.100 --> 00:28:55.660
If you're not passionate and

557
00:28:55.660 --> 00:28:58.520
committed to the team,
they will not be committed to you.

558
00:28:58.520 --> 00:29:00.370
It's just that straightforward.

559
00:29:00.370 --> 00:29:04.340
So we're gonna look at someone who, and
it doesn't mean you gotta be bombastic and

560
00:29:04.340 --> 00:29:07.540
jumping up and down and
giving big speeches.

561
00:29:07.540 --> 00:29:10.260
They just need to see that you're
deeply committed yourself.

562
00:29:10.260 --> 00:29:12.780
That you're passionate, that you're
excited, you love working with them,

563
00:29:12.780 --> 00:29:15.410
you respect the other people on the team.

564
00:29:15.410 --> 00:29:17.670
You see them as partners and peers.

565
00:29:17.670 --> 00:29:21.470
And you're excited about what
we're gonna do together.

566
00:29:21.470 --> 00:29:24.950
The last two are fair and supportive.

567
00:29:24.950 --> 00:29:26.300
That if you're gonna lead the team.

568
00:29:26.300 --> 00:29:29.050
And we've gotta treat everybody
on the team the same.

569
00:29:29.050 --> 00:29:32.719
We gotta be fair, we gotta have fair
rules, fair work hours, fair work loads.

570
00:29:33.890 --> 00:29:36.230
And that I'm there to coach my people,
support them,

571
00:29:36.230 --> 00:29:39.100
train them, be there when they need me.

572
00:29:39.100 --> 00:29:42.850
When something goes wrong, when they're
struggling, I'm there to support them,

573
00:29:42.850 --> 00:29:46.070
help them, get them coaching,
more training, more resources.

574
00:29:46.070 --> 00:29:48.320
So roughly,
what we've put together here, and

575
00:29:48.320 --> 00:29:52.910
this is based on a large research project
by two of my colleagues, and Pozner.

576
00:29:52.910 --> 00:29:56.420
Let me take all that research and boil it
down to these six things that people look

577
00:29:56.420 --> 00:29:59.840
for in a team leader they
would willingly follow.

578
00:29:59.840 --> 00:30:03.280
I want someone who will tell me the truth,
who has a clear idea where the team is

579
00:30:03.280 --> 00:30:08.370
going, is excited to go there with all of
us, is really good at what they do and

580
00:30:08.370 --> 00:30:13.310
they're passionate about it, they treat
me fairly and support me along the way.

581
00:30:13.310 --> 00:30:17.590
if you've got a leader as a team
leader that does those things,

582
00:30:17.590 --> 00:30:20.220
you've got one that people will
be strongly committed to and

583
00:30:20.220 --> 00:30:23.610
because they are committed to the team
leader they are committed to the team.

584
00:30:23.610 --> 00:30:26.720
>> Makes a lot of sense and
that sounds like the basis for

585
00:30:26.720 --> 00:30:29.030
a really strong team if
you have that trust and

586
00:30:29.030 --> 00:30:31.720
that commitment from everyone
from the top all the way down.

587
00:30:31.720 --> 00:30:33.700
Any final thoughts on this topic?

588
00:30:33.700 --> 00:30:37.590
>> Yeah I think we can summarize
this entire topic to two key ideas,

589
00:30:37.590 --> 00:30:38.620
no trust, no commitment.

590
00:30:38.620 --> 00:30:39.930
Its that simple.

591
00:30:39.930 --> 00:30:40.585
>> That works for me.

592
00:30:40.585 --> 00:30:42.690
>> [LAUGH]
>> Well, I think that's a great place for

593
00:30:42.690 --> 00:30:43.930
us to end for this episode.

594
00:30:43.930 --> 00:30:47.800
I know we've got a lot more great content
coming you way on building these teams.

595
00:30:47.800 --> 00:30:51.440
But that's gonna do it for this one so
we're gonna go ahead and sign off.

596
00:30:51.440 --> 00:30:53.050
I've been your host Peter VanRysdam.

597
00:30:53.050 --> 00:30:54.040
>> I'm John Spence.

598
00:30:54.040 --> 00:30:56.378
>> And we'll see you next time.

599
00:30:56.378 --> 00:31:06.378
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: Being superb at effective communications is critical for the success of a team. In this session, you will learn how to ask great questions, the five levels of listening, positive body language, negative body language, social styles and other essential communications tools. You will also look at how to increase collaboration and five levels of conflict that inhibit team collaboration.
episodes.title: Team Communication and Collaboration
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:04.818
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:04.818 --> 00:00:07.030
Hello and welcome to BizProTV.

3
00:00:07.030 --> 00:00:08.370
I'm your host Peter Van Rysdam.

4
00:00:08.370 --> 00:00:12.765
And today we are continuing our series
about leading technology teams.

5
00:00:12.765 --> 00:00:15.375
And specifically in this episode
we're going to talk about, and

6
00:00:15.375 --> 00:00:17.345
I'm gonna look at my notes,
this one's a tongue twister,

7
00:00:17.345 --> 00:00:21.015
fostering effective team communication and
collaboration.

8
00:00:21.015 --> 00:00:24.568
And here to help us with that, we have
an expert on all of those things I assume.

9
00:00:24.568 --> 00:00:25.461
>> [LAUGH]
>> I hope.

10
00:00:25.461 --> 00:00:26.547
Mr. John Spence.

11
00:00:26.547 --> 00:00:27.247
John, how are you doing?

12
00:00:27.247 --> 00:00:28.227
>> Great, Pete, how are you?

13
00:00:28.227 --> 00:00:28.917
>> I'm fantastic.

14
00:00:28.917 --> 00:00:29.470
>> Good, good.

15
00:00:29.470 --> 00:00:31.134
>> So what are we talking about today,

16
00:00:31.134 --> 00:00:34.377
with fostering communication
collaboration?

17
00:00:34.377 --> 00:00:35.887
>> The communication topic is one,

18
00:00:35.887 --> 00:00:39.747
that's pretty in-depth,
I got a lot to cover in this session.

19
00:00:39.747 --> 00:00:42.677
But I wanna say the very beginning,
that this isn't something you learn

20
00:00:42.677 --> 00:00:46.077
by just watching one of my sessions,
or one of our sessions.

21
00:00:46.077 --> 00:00:47.840
This takes practice.

22
00:00:47.840 --> 00:00:50.090
I've been teaching these things for
over two decades, and

23
00:00:50.090 --> 00:00:53.380
on a scale of 1 to 10 of being
an excellent communicator,

24
00:00:53.380 --> 00:00:56.450
I give myself about a 7,
maybe not so much other days.

25
00:00:56.450 --> 00:00:58.660
This is hard stuff that
you gotta practice.

26
00:00:58.660 --> 00:01:04.365
A couple of reasons, that people don't
realize is, roughly from the research and

27
00:01:04.365 --> 00:01:09.600
stuff I've seen,
about 93% of communications is nonverbal.

28
00:01:09.600 --> 00:01:13.240
It's your tone of voice,
it's your body language, it's eye contact.

29
00:01:13.240 --> 00:01:14.600
We're going to be going to all this.

30
00:01:14.600 --> 00:01:18.272
But realize that the words that
actually come out of your mouth,

31
00:01:18.272 --> 00:01:21.202
are a small fraction of
the actual communication.

32
00:01:21.202 --> 00:01:23.301
And you might be able to
say the right thing, but

33
00:01:23.301 --> 00:01:27.070
if everything else isn't working,
then the message isn't delivered.

34
00:01:27.070 --> 00:01:28.940
Which is another important
idea around that,

35
00:01:28.940 --> 00:01:33.350
is it doesn't matter what you say,
it matters what they heard.

36
00:01:33.350 --> 00:01:37.130
If I can communicate something, and
I think I got it, I'm strong and

37
00:01:37.130 --> 00:01:40.680
I know it, and the other person heard it
a different way, didn't understand it,

38
00:01:40.680 --> 00:01:45.550
was confused, didn't understand the terms,
that's not their fault, that's your fault.

39
00:01:45.550 --> 00:01:47.520
That means you have to be
a better communicator.

40
00:01:48.910 --> 00:01:51.810
And the other big thing around this, and
why we're gonna spend so much time on it

41
00:01:51.810 --> 00:01:56.790
is, I don't think most people, me
included, are constantly monitoring their

42
00:01:56.790 --> 00:02:01.880
own communication styles, skills, tools,
and just sort of take if for granted.

43
00:02:01.880 --> 00:02:02.930
You know?
I was born.

44
00:02:02.930 --> 00:02:04.060
I got a mouth, two ears.

45
00:02:04.060 --> 00:02:05.170
I can talk, I can listen.

46
00:02:05.170 --> 00:02:07.280
I'm fine.
I don't need to work on this.

47
00:02:07.280 --> 00:02:09.898
Truth is, this takes a lot of
work it's very challenging.

48
00:02:09.898 --> 00:02:13.908
>> Yeah, and they may be thinking about
what they're saying, but like you said,

49
00:02:13.908 --> 00:02:16.540
93% is non-verbal, so
you might not be thinking about

50
00:02:16.540 --> 00:02:20.710
how you're saying something, or how you're
showing your body language at that time.

51
00:02:20.710 --> 00:02:24.380
So, that's definitely something that
we want to try to understand, so

52
00:02:24.380 --> 00:02:26.270
we can make sure we're
sending the right message.

53
00:02:26.270 --> 00:02:28.770
>> Yeah, and well we're gonna
hit that in depth today, but

54
00:02:28.770 --> 00:02:30.679
I wanna start with
the verbal communication.

55
00:02:31.730 --> 00:02:38.120
And, I did a huge research study years
ago, on, for high potential employees,

56
00:02:38.120 --> 00:02:41.900
looking at things that they look for
in other people on their team,

57
00:02:41.900 --> 00:02:44.420
who they wanna work with, and
the leader they would willingly follow.

58
00:02:44.420 --> 00:02:47.110
And one of the big things,
was communication.

59
00:02:48.110 --> 00:02:50.890
But it wasn't communication,
as being able to stand up and talk and

60
00:02:50.890 --> 00:02:53.660
tell stories and get people motivated.

61
00:02:53.660 --> 00:02:55.770
The two things they said
that were most important,

62
00:02:55.770 --> 00:02:59.970
were asking really good questions,
and being an intense listener.

63
00:02:59.970 --> 00:03:03.100
Asking just the right question, at just
the right time to get people talking,

64
00:03:03.100 --> 00:03:04.660
thinking, being innovative.

65
00:03:04.660 --> 00:03:07.880
And then being incredibly good at
listening and taking notes and

66
00:03:07.880 --> 00:03:10.930
absorbing that information,
when someone else was speaking.

67
00:03:10.930 --> 00:03:14.930
So, I'm going to share with you now
seven different types of questions.

68
00:03:14.930 --> 00:03:17.750
And I'm gonna look at my notes to
make sure I cover all of them.

69
00:03:17.750 --> 00:03:23.100
But this is from years and years of
teaching consultative sales skills.

70
00:03:23.100 --> 00:03:27.900
And if there's anyone that's a master
of asking really good questions,

71
00:03:27.900 --> 00:03:32.340
it's sales people, consultative,
because you're being a consultant.

72
00:03:32.340 --> 00:03:33.930
It's like being a doctor.

73
00:03:33.930 --> 00:03:36.580
Or trying to understand it deeply,
we have to ask great questions.

74
00:03:36.580 --> 00:03:41.431
So, first question I'm gonna talk about,
I think this one's fairly simple, but

75
00:03:41.431 --> 00:03:45.399
still important to understand,
is open ended versus close ended.

76
00:03:45.399 --> 00:03:48.480
And it's pretty easy to understand this.

77
00:03:48.480 --> 00:03:50.870
A close ended question, is one that
could be answered by yes or no.

78
00:03:52.150 --> 00:03:53.700
How's everything going?

79
00:03:53.700 --> 00:03:54.200
Great.

80
00:03:55.520 --> 00:03:56.720
Did you finish the project?

81
00:03:56.720 --> 00:03:57.220
Yes.

82
00:03:58.220 --> 00:03:59.180
Are you on schedule?

83
00:03:59.180 --> 00:04:00.190
No.

84
00:04:00.190 --> 00:04:04.980
A open ended question, forces the person
to give you more information.

85
00:04:04.980 --> 00:04:07.210
Instead of, is the project on schedule?

86
00:04:07.210 --> 00:04:08.230
Yes.

87
00:04:08.230 --> 00:04:09.550
Help me understand the milestones, and

88
00:04:09.550 --> 00:04:13.150
where we stand against each one of
them right now, I can't just go yes.

89
00:04:13.150 --> 00:04:14.330
I've gotta give somewhat.

90
00:04:14.330 --> 00:04:18.730
And if you want to get an answer quickly,
and you just need a yes or

91
00:04:18.730 --> 00:04:20.600
no, you ask a closed ended question.

92
00:04:20.600 --> 00:04:22.140
Because if you ask
an open-ended question there,

93
00:04:22.140 --> 00:04:25.290
then you get all kinds of
information that was unnecessary.

94
00:04:25.290 --> 00:04:28.160
The reverse is, if you need more
information you have to make sure that

95
00:04:28.160 --> 00:04:30.140
you're asking open-ended questions.

96
00:04:30.140 --> 00:04:33.690
So, let me give you a couple
of tools around doing that.

97
00:04:33.690 --> 00:04:37.200
The first one is what I call a cushion.

98
00:04:37.200 --> 00:04:39.800
And a cushion is something
you put on the front of,

99
00:04:39.800 --> 00:04:44.930
and these are usually difficult or
probing or focused questions.

100
00:04:44.930 --> 00:04:46.670
You can't just ask one after the other.

101
00:04:46.670 --> 00:04:48.485
It starts to sound like
the Spanish Inquisition.

102
00:04:48.485 --> 00:04:52.680
[LAUGH] So we want to ease through, it so
it doesn't sound like an interrogation.

103
00:04:52.680 --> 00:04:55.640
And one of the ways to do that,
is what's called a cushion.

104
00:04:55.640 --> 00:04:59.250
And a cushion is something you put on the
front of the question to say, in order for

105
00:04:59.250 --> 00:05:03.170
me to be able to help you, so
that I can better understand,

106
00:05:03.170 --> 00:05:06.270
to make sure that we get this
project done on time together.

107
00:05:06.270 --> 00:05:10.030
These are things that say, I'm about
to ask you a challenging question, and

108
00:05:10.030 --> 00:05:15.200
one that I'd like a good clear answer for,
but I'm doing it to help you.

109
00:05:15.200 --> 00:05:16.270
Or I'm doing it to help the team.

110
00:05:16.270 --> 00:05:17.720
I'm not just interrogating you.

111
00:05:17.720 --> 00:05:22.800
So, in order for me to better understand,
so that we can keep the project on.

112
00:05:22.800 --> 00:05:27.780
In order to make sure that everybody is
in alignment, could you take a minute or

113
00:05:27.780 --> 00:05:30.400
two and share with me x, y, z?

114
00:05:30.400 --> 00:05:34.030
So I'm doing this because I'm trying
to help you, I'm trying to help us.

115
00:05:34.030 --> 00:05:35.230
It's a cushion.

116
00:05:35.230 --> 00:05:37.860
The other one is called a condition.

117
00:05:37.860 --> 00:05:42.760
And a conditioning statement says,
I saw something, I talked to someone.

118
00:05:42.760 --> 00:05:44.110
I got new information, and

119
00:05:44.110 --> 00:05:49.770
because of that new condition information,
I have to ask you this question.

120
00:05:49.770 --> 00:05:51.750
I was talking to one of
the other folks on the team, and

121
00:05:51.750 --> 00:05:55.790
I understand you're slipping
a little bit on some of your goals.

122
00:05:55.790 --> 00:05:58.080
Tell me about that, so I can help you.

123
00:05:58.080 --> 00:06:00.930
I looked at the report that you generated,
and

124
00:06:00.930 --> 00:06:03.290
I noticed there was a few
things missing from that.

125
00:06:03.290 --> 00:06:04.999
Could we take a few
minutes to discuss that?

126
00:06:06.070 --> 00:06:08.270
I just met with our team sponsor, and

127
00:06:08.270 --> 00:06:11.230
she said that they're gonna
need to move up the timeline.

128
00:06:11.230 --> 00:06:14.290
Let me ask you some questions about where
you stand on the project right now.

129
00:06:14.290 --> 00:06:16.630
So it's not me,
that wants to ask this question.

130
00:06:16.630 --> 00:06:20.580
I have new information, I read something,
I saw something, I talked to somebody, and

131
00:06:20.580 --> 00:06:23.900
because of that,
I am now asking you this question.

132
00:06:23.900 --> 00:06:27.970
The next one I wanna look at, and this is
a fun one, are what I call, expansion or

133
00:06:27.970 --> 00:06:29.760
contraction questions.

134
00:06:29.760 --> 00:06:33.790
If you talk to somebody who, even when
you ask them an open-ended question,

135
00:06:33.790 --> 00:06:38.240
answers it with yes or no or two to three
words, and you need more information,

136
00:06:38.240 --> 00:06:42.340
you ask the question in a way to
get them to expand their answer.

137
00:06:42.340 --> 00:06:44.040
It sounds like this, Peter.

138
00:06:44.040 --> 00:06:46.180
Peter, could you take the next three or
four minutes,

139
00:06:46.180 --> 00:06:51.220
and in as much detail as possible,
tell me everything you know about blah.

140
00:06:51.220 --> 00:06:52.840
So, I would say,
how long are you gonna talk?

141
00:06:52.840 --> 00:06:53.870
Three or four minutes.

142
00:06:53.870 --> 00:06:54.870
How much are you gonna tell me?

143
00:06:54.870 --> 00:06:55.690
Everything.

144
00:06:55.690 --> 00:06:58.580
And what that does is, it earns me the
right that if Peter just says blah, blah,

145
00:06:58.580 --> 00:07:00.810
blah three or four things,
I can go, what else?

146
00:07:00.810 --> 00:07:02.020
Is there anything else?

147
00:07:02.020 --> 00:07:04.470
Or I could say,
could you take the next four minutes and

148
00:07:04.470 --> 00:07:07.070
tell me the top five
things you're focused on?

149
00:07:07.070 --> 00:07:10.160
And if the person I'm talking
to can only come up with three,

150
00:07:10.160 --> 00:07:13.080
I have earned the right to say,
what are two more?

151
00:07:13.080 --> 00:07:15.640
So, I have earned the right through
asking the question to say,

152
00:07:15.640 --> 00:07:19.150
youre going to talk a long time,
youre going to give me detail,

153
00:07:19.150 --> 00:07:22.070
youre giving me five points,
six points, whatever it is.

154
00:07:22.070 --> 00:07:25.930
And I can push you, for more and more
information, if you dont give me enough.

155
00:07:25.930 --> 00:07:28.640
I want you to expand your answer.

156
00:07:28.640 --> 00:07:31.396
Now the reverse, is when you talk
to somebody and you go, hey,

157
00:07:31.396 --> 00:07:32.340
Dave what time is it?

158
00:07:32.340 --> 00:07:36.037
And they go, in 1643 the German's
invented the first and

159
00:07:36.037 --> 00:07:40.157
they start to tell you about how clocks
are built, and the whole history of time,

160
00:07:40.157 --> 00:07:43.460
and you're just like,
I just need to know what time it is.

161
00:07:43.460 --> 00:07:47.136
So if you got somebody that gives you
a long answer to something you just

162
00:07:47.136 --> 00:07:49.332
want a yes or no, you give a contraction.

163
00:07:49.332 --> 00:07:54.163
And the contraction says is, Stephanie,
could you take a minute or less and share

164
00:07:54.163 --> 00:07:58.795
with me the two most important things,
I need to help you with on this project?

165
00:07:58.795 --> 00:08:03.088
Tim Could you in 130 seconds
just give me the single most

166
00:08:03.088 --> 00:08:05.990
important thing we need to talk about?

167
00:08:05.990 --> 00:08:09.585
All right everybody, I need everyone on
the team to give me their feedback but

168
00:08:09.585 --> 00:08:12.650
I'd like each of you to take
absolutely no more than one minute.

169
00:08:12.650 --> 00:08:15.630
Cuz there's always one team member
where this person talks for a minute,

170
00:08:15.630 --> 00:08:19.840
this person talks for 45 seconds, and
then this person talks for 13 minutes.

171
00:08:19.840 --> 00:08:22.540
And the rest of the team is rolling
their eyes and going crazy.

172
00:08:22.540 --> 00:08:24.090
And they're going on and on and on.

173
00:08:24.090 --> 00:08:27.650
So by putting a limit on how
long someone can talk, or

174
00:08:27.650 --> 00:08:32.620
a limit on how much information they
give you, you can contract their answer.

175
00:08:32.620 --> 00:08:36.030
These are both very handy
types of questions.

176
00:08:36.030 --> 00:08:39.530
The next one is what I call scale
questions, and I love these.

177
00:08:39.530 --> 00:08:44.130
A scale question says,
on a scale of one to ten,

178
00:08:44.130 --> 00:08:50.530
with ten being extremely confident and
zero being totally no confidence at all.

179
00:08:50.530 --> 00:08:53.920
How confident are you on being
able to meet that deadline?

180
00:08:53.920 --> 00:08:56.680
And if the person goes nine,
you go great, we're good, I'm happy.

181
00:08:56.680 --> 00:08:57.950
The person goes five, you go all right,

182
00:08:57.950 --> 00:08:59.940
what is it gonna take
to get it to a seven?

183
00:08:59.940 --> 00:09:04.450
And that's the same thing about a scale
question is, I can judge someone's

184
00:09:04.450 --> 00:09:11.240
concern, distress, emotions,
anger, whatever it might be,

185
00:09:11.240 --> 00:09:15.810
by saying on a scale of one to ten, or a
scale of one to five, I know you're upset.

186
00:09:15.810 --> 00:09:18.600
I can see that you're angry.

187
00:09:18.600 --> 00:09:23.030
On a scale of one to ten, how frustrated
and angry you're feeling right now?

188
00:09:23.030 --> 00:09:23.620
Ten.

189
00:09:23.620 --> 00:09:26.870
Okay, were gonna need to take sometime
to sit down and talk about this.

190
00:09:26.870 --> 00:09:28.750
I'll give you a quick story on this.

191
00:09:28.750 --> 00:09:33.330
I've been an owner CEO of several
companies and I know that when

192
00:09:33.330 --> 00:09:37.396
I use to talk to my staff, what I would
say if something wasn't going right or

193
00:09:37.396 --> 00:09:39.507
a project wasn't going right,
I was displeased.

194
00:09:39.507 --> 00:09:44.790
I would just come to my staff,
pull them all together and say, on

195
00:09:44.790 --> 00:09:50.220
the Jones project, on a scale of one to
ten of being pleased how things are going,

196
00:09:50.220 --> 00:09:51.950
I'm at a negative three.

197
00:09:51.950 --> 00:09:54.580
And then everyone would jump up and run
around, I didn't have to yell, didn't have

198
00:09:54.580 --> 00:09:58.770
to scream, just had to say, this is where
I sit on this rating and it's not good.

199
00:09:58.770 --> 00:10:02.230
So great way to elicit concern,
issue, emotions.

200
00:10:02.230 --> 00:10:04.250
Scale of one to five, scale of one to ten.

201
00:10:04.250 --> 00:10:07.510
They give you a number and you say
great or you say the number is low.

202
00:10:07.510 --> 00:10:12.205
How can we get it higher and make you feel
better or get the project back on track?

203
00:10:12.205 --> 00:10:16.004
As you are asking all these questions,
there is a another one,

204
00:10:16.004 --> 00:10:18.700
a tiny little sort of question to ask.

205
00:10:18.700 --> 00:10:21.140
Which is, while people are talking or
you are asking questions,

206
00:10:21.140 --> 00:10:24.770
what I call perception checking questions,
perception checking.

207
00:10:24.770 --> 00:10:25.520
And here's what those are.

208
00:10:25.520 --> 00:10:27.210
Do you feel like we're on track?

209
00:10:27.210 --> 00:10:28.890
We're going along, is this a good pace?

210
00:10:28.890 --> 00:10:30.820
Are we covering everything
that's important to you?

211
00:10:30.820 --> 00:10:33.866
So you can see in a team setting that
you could look around and say, Peter,

212
00:10:33.866 --> 00:10:34.913
everything going good?

213
00:10:34.913 --> 00:10:36.295
Kim, are you doing all right?

214
00:10:36.295 --> 00:10:37.580
Vicky, is everything good?

215
00:10:37.580 --> 00:10:40.550
Tim, are you feel like we're covering
the things that are most important to you?

216
00:10:40.550 --> 00:10:42.050
Those little perception check,

217
00:10:42.050 --> 00:10:45.250
keep everybody involve and
then you watch the body language.

218
00:10:45.250 --> 00:10:47.593
If I say, Vicky,
do you feel comfortable about everything?

219
00:10:47.593 --> 00:10:51.310
And she goes, then I know that's not true.

220
00:10:51.310 --> 00:10:56.480
So, I gotta stop it and now I can tell,
it seems to me from your body language

221
00:10:56.480 --> 00:11:00.170
that you're not fully excited about this,
something's wrong.

222
00:11:00.170 --> 00:11:02.500
So, let's talk about this,
let me hear more.

223
00:11:02.500 --> 00:11:06.270
So now you see where the words and
the body language become really strong.

224
00:11:06.270 --> 00:11:09.711
I can say yes, but
if my yes is like, yeah,

225
00:11:09.711 --> 00:11:14.460
that's good, it's very clear from
my body language it is a no.

226
00:11:14.460 --> 00:11:17.660
So the perception checking keeps everybody
in, you're looking at body language,

227
00:11:17.660 --> 00:11:21.490
you're looking for eye contact, you're
making sure you're going at a good pace.

228
00:11:21.490 --> 00:11:25.400
And then the last ones
are relationship questions.

229
00:11:25.400 --> 00:11:29.290
And when we talk about teams, this is
that team trust, team commitment, and

230
00:11:29.290 --> 00:11:30.750
these are pretty simple.

231
00:11:30.750 --> 00:11:31.860
Do you feel good about this?

232
00:11:31.860 --> 00:11:32.680
Are you comfortable?

233
00:11:34.180 --> 00:11:37.520
Am I addressing the things that
are most important to you?

234
00:11:37.520 --> 00:11:39.750
Do all of you feel like we're
getting along well together on this,

235
00:11:39.750 --> 00:11:40.840
that we're all committed?

236
00:11:40.840 --> 00:11:44.320
Those are all relationship questions
about how are we doing together,

237
00:11:44.320 --> 00:11:46.130
how is the team working together?

238
00:11:46.130 --> 00:11:49.274
I've just given you seven,
I'm gonna read them off my list.

239
00:11:49.274 --> 00:11:53.610
Open ended versus closed, cushions,
conditions, expansion contraction,

240
00:11:53.610 --> 00:11:57.820
scale questions, perception checking,
and relationship questions.

241
00:11:57.820 --> 00:12:01.660
These are very powerful tools but
you have to practice them.

242
00:12:01.660 --> 00:12:05.090
You got to work on them, you got to think
them through, you can't do it on the fly.

243
00:12:05.090 --> 00:12:08.390
But here's what I will tell you,
if you can start to build this into your

244
00:12:08.390 --> 00:12:13.340
communications skills and styles,
it will make you a superb questioner.

245
00:12:14.470 --> 00:12:19.460
>> Great, so I guess, the next step
is if someone is asking question,

246
00:12:19.460 --> 00:12:20.830
someone else has to be listening to them.

247
00:12:20.830 --> 00:12:23.000
What makes someone a good listener?

248
00:12:23.000 --> 00:12:24.570
>> Yeah, you bring up a really good point,

249
00:12:24.570 --> 00:12:26.572
cuz usually someone else
should be listening to them.

250
00:12:26.572 --> 00:12:28.969
>> I know.
>> Because if you ask a great question and

251
00:12:28.969 --> 00:12:32.110
the person gives you all
this great information.

252
00:12:32.110 --> 00:12:35.336
I ask an expansion question with
a cushion and a condition on it.

253
00:12:35.336 --> 00:12:39.030
In order for me to be able to help you,
I was talking to our sponsor and

254
00:12:39.030 --> 00:12:43.230
she said they're gonna have to move
the project due date up a couple weeks.

255
00:12:43.230 --> 00:12:48.400
I'd like for you to take 10 or 15 minutes
and share with me all of your concerns.

256
00:12:48.400 --> 00:12:53.460
I've just put a cushion, condition,
and an expansion on that one.

257
00:12:53.460 --> 00:12:57.080
And now I'm expecting this person
on my team to give me five or

258
00:12:57.080 --> 00:12:58.580
ten minutes of feedback.

259
00:12:58.580 --> 00:13:02.690
And if she or he starts giving me all that
and I'm not listening, I'm not writing

260
00:13:02.690 --> 00:13:05.510
notes, I'm not paying attention,
you know what you're telling them?

261
00:13:05.510 --> 00:13:07.910
I don't care about you and
don't talk to me.

262
00:13:07.910 --> 00:13:11.450
Don't give me long answers cuz I'm not
listening anyways and I won't remember it.

263
00:13:11.450 --> 00:13:12.480
And then what happens the next time,

264
00:13:12.480 --> 00:13:16.090
you don't even bother to ask them
the question, or they don't even bother to

265
00:13:16.090 --> 00:13:18.660
answer your questions,
cuz they know you're not listening.

266
00:13:18.660 --> 00:13:21.410
So there are five levels of listening.

267
00:13:21.410 --> 00:13:22.510
We'll go through this.

268
00:13:22.510 --> 00:13:24.720
Level one, not listening at all.

269
00:13:24.720 --> 00:13:28.006
I'm shut off, I've got bad body language,
I'm shaking my head.

270
00:13:28.006 --> 00:13:30.930
I've got nothing, I'm not connected.

271
00:13:30.930 --> 00:13:33.800
And unfortunately we see this
on teams where people shut down.

272
00:13:33.800 --> 00:13:37.020
You can see some of them pushes away from
the table in a meeting, they crossed their

273
00:13:37.020 --> 00:13:41.810
arms, they looked out the window, they've
put on their cellphone, they're completely

274
00:13:41.810 --> 00:13:46.770
out which leads me to level two
which is distracted listening.

275
00:13:46.770 --> 00:13:50.260
I'm kinda listening with a half an ear,
I'm checking my email,

276
00:13:50.260 --> 00:13:54.240
posting something on Facebook,
putting out a Tweet, something like that.

277
00:13:54.240 --> 00:13:56.170
I'm shuffling through some papers.

278
00:13:56.170 --> 00:13:58.580
I'm looking at my watch thinking
about the next meeting.

279
00:13:58.580 --> 00:14:01.720
I'm leaning in a little bit,
I'm kind of there, but

280
00:14:01.720 --> 00:14:04.630
I'm only about 20% there, distracted.

281
00:14:04.630 --> 00:14:07.980
The next level is, and
this is one we got a lot too,

282
00:14:07.980 --> 00:14:12.790
is listening simply to answer,
to give your point of view immediately.

283
00:14:12.790 --> 00:14:15.881
So I'm not listening to understand you,
I'm just listening to reply.

284
00:14:15.881 --> 00:14:17.420
I'm thinking about my great answer.

285
00:14:17.420 --> 00:14:20.834
How it's gonna make me look smart and
bright and talented and innovative, and

286
00:14:20.834 --> 00:14:22.030
all those things.

287
00:14:22.030 --> 00:14:23.980
And you're asking me this great
question and all I'm thinking about is,

288
00:14:23.980 --> 00:14:26.880
as soon as he shuts up,
this is what I'm gonna say.

289
00:14:26.880 --> 00:14:28.670
Or, they're angry and mad and
they don't hear your argument,

290
00:14:28.670 --> 00:14:32.440
they just think about how will I defend
against this, what's my argument?

291
00:14:32.440 --> 00:14:36.670
So, we've got not listening at all,
distracted listening,

292
00:14:36.670 --> 00:14:41.460
listening just to answer and
those three are obviously unacceptable.

293
00:14:41.460 --> 00:14:44.740
The next one is what I
call engaged listening.

294
00:14:44.740 --> 00:14:47.740
Engaged listening is I've
shut down my machines.

295
00:14:47.740 --> 00:14:49.385
I've turned off my computer.

296
00:14:49.385 --> 00:14:51.360
I've moved the papers away.

297
00:14:51.360 --> 00:14:54.900
I've got a clean pad out,
I'm taking some notes.

298
00:14:54.900 --> 00:14:59.330
I'm really trying to listen and
get the information you're giving me.

299
00:14:59.330 --> 00:15:03.440
I'm trying to understand the message
very clearly and I'm engaged, and

300
00:15:03.440 --> 00:15:07.100
I've shut everything else out,
and you've got my attention.

301
00:15:07.100 --> 00:15:10.590
I am locked up and
I am listening to gather information.

302
00:15:10.590 --> 00:15:12.870
This is really where you
need to be on a team.

303
00:15:12.870 --> 00:15:14.620
This shows commitment to the team.

304
00:15:14.620 --> 00:15:16.360
It shows that you care
about what you're doing.

305
00:15:16.360 --> 00:15:19.090
It shows that you're interested and
passionate and

306
00:15:19.090 --> 00:15:23.210
without this level of listening on a team,
it's very hard to have an effective team.

307
00:15:23.210 --> 00:15:26.410
So engaged listening is
the level you want to get to.

308
00:15:26.410 --> 00:15:30.110
There's one level beyond that, and you've
seen me express a little bit on this

309
00:15:30.110 --> 00:15:34.610
video, is listening not just to understand
the information and what was said, but

310
00:15:34.610 --> 00:15:39.530
listening to hear what wasn't said, what
was left out, or the emotions involved.

311
00:15:39.530 --> 00:15:42.450
I gave the example before that
you ask someone in the group,

312
00:15:42.450 --> 00:15:45.160
you feel good about this,
and they go, pretty good.

313
00:15:45.160 --> 00:15:48.536
What they have clearly told you,
even though the words stay good,

314
00:15:48.536 --> 00:15:50.841
the body language says, no, I'm not good.

315
00:15:50.841 --> 00:15:54.243
I'm upset, I'm concerned,
I'm frustrated, I'm scared,

316
00:15:54.243 --> 00:15:56.076
I don't think this is a good idea.

317
00:15:56.076 --> 00:16:01.034
And if you're just listening, you'll take
the yes, go yes, okay, she's on board,

318
00:16:01.034 --> 00:16:05.657
that's fine If you're at the highest
level, which is listening to understand,

319
00:16:05.657 --> 00:16:08.806
not just what they are saying but
what they don't say and

320
00:16:08.806 --> 00:16:11.410
the emotions, then you go stop.

321
00:16:11.410 --> 00:16:13.470
We need to back up here for a second.

322
00:16:13.470 --> 00:16:16.390
I can tell you're not
fully onboard with this.

323
00:16:16.390 --> 00:16:20.030
I listened to you very carefully, and
I can see through your body language,

324
00:16:20.030 --> 00:16:21.270
it seems that you're upset.

325
00:16:22.290 --> 00:16:23.820
So those are the five levels.

326
00:16:23.820 --> 00:16:27.350
And really it's the engaged listening and
then the advanced listening for

327
00:16:27.350 --> 00:16:30.960
emotion and what's not said that
we try to get to on a team.

328
00:16:30.960 --> 00:16:33.570
Now how do you prove
that you were listening?

329
00:16:33.570 --> 00:16:36.610
Very important, and
I just started to model it there.

330
00:16:36.610 --> 00:16:39.380
It's summarizing and paraphrasing.

331
00:16:39.380 --> 00:16:42.450
Summarizing says,
I've listening to you very carefully.

332
00:16:42.450 --> 00:16:46.440
Talk for about five minutes,
and you covered five things.

333
00:16:46.440 --> 00:16:50.097
And it was one, two, three,
four, and five, is that correct?

334
00:16:50.097 --> 00:16:52.080
And then the person says, yes, you got it.

335
00:16:52.080 --> 00:16:53.850
I got it right here on my notes, I got it.

336
00:16:53.850 --> 00:16:55.152
And what that says, I heard you, and

337
00:16:55.152 --> 00:16:56.833
I listened to the information
very carefully.

338
00:16:56.833 --> 00:17:01.200
And I've written down the information,
I'll remember the information.

339
00:17:01.200 --> 00:17:05.230
That's good, that shows that you
are engaged and you're listening.

340
00:17:05.230 --> 00:17:07.270
The next level is paraphrasing.

341
00:17:07.270 --> 00:17:11.250
And what paraphrasing says is,
I've listened to you carefully,

342
00:17:11.250 --> 00:17:14.360
you said there were five things.

343
00:17:14.360 --> 00:17:17.950
In priority, though, you said that
number four was the most important.

344
00:17:17.950 --> 00:17:20.330
Number two was the second most important.

345
00:17:20.330 --> 00:17:22.251
Number three was the third most important.

346
00:17:22.251 --> 00:17:25.450
Number five, I even got lost there.

347
00:17:25.450 --> 00:17:28.390
But basically say, you said A, B, C and D.

348
00:17:28.390 --> 00:17:29.510
A is the most important.

349
00:17:29.510 --> 00:17:31.240
D is the second most important.

350
00:17:31.240 --> 00:17:33.260
B and C are about the same.

351
00:17:33.260 --> 00:17:38.070
And from everything you said, it sounds
to me like you're focused on this.

352
00:17:38.070 --> 00:17:41.119
So I've went from, I listened to you,
here's what you said.

353
00:17:41.119 --> 00:17:45.940
To I've listened to you and to me,
it seems like you said this.

354
00:17:45.940 --> 00:17:48.030
Summarizing shows you pay attention.

355
00:17:48.030 --> 00:17:51.730
Paraphrasing shows that you
understood what they said well enough

356
00:17:51.730 --> 00:17:53.890
that you can give it back
to them in your own words.

357
00:17:53.890 --> 00:17:56.100
And they go yes,
that's exactly what I meant.

358
00:17:56.100 --> 00:18:00.110
When you get to that level,
you have clearly shown, I listened to you,

359
00:18:00.110 --> 00:18:02.520
I'm engaged, I took notes.

360
00:18:02.520 --> 00:18:06.399
I understood what you said, and
I understood it so well that I can tell it

361
00:18:06.399 --> 00:18:10.228
back to you the way I understand it and
you agree that I have it down pat.

362
00:18:10.228 --> 00:18:11.600
>> All right, great, John.

363
00:18:11.600 --> 00:18:16.275
I wanna go back to something you said
earlier on about the percentage of

364
00:18:16.275 --> 00:18:18.175
communication that is non-verbal.

365
00:18:18.175 --> 00:18:20.145
So body language has to
be a huge part of that.

366
00:18:20.145 --> 00:18:21.295
Can we talk about that a little bit?

367
00:18:21.295 --> 00:18:23.505
>> Yeah, body language is huge.

368
00:18:23.505 --> 00:18:26.235
And this is also one of the reasons
it's hard to do with virtual teams

369
00:18:26.235 --> 00:18:27.885
that just do telephone calls.

370
00:18:27.885 --> 00:18:30.115
Cuz you could be listening
to this information, but

371
00:18:30.115 --> 00:18:34.010
if you don't see what someone else is
doing, you're missing a major part of it.

372
00:18:34.010 --> 00:18:37.680
So let's talk about both positive and
negative body language.

373
00:18:37.680 --> 00:18:40.570
Positive body language has six or
seven elements.

374
00:18:40.570 --> 00:18:41.430
Here they are.

375
00:18:41.430 --> 00:18:44.130
First of all, you wanna have an open
stance towards the other person.

376
00:18:44.130 --> 00:18:47.660
If I'm talking to Peter, I wanna face
him because if I don't face Peter and

377
00:18:47.660 --> 00:18:51.640
I'm talking to him like this,
I'm clearly not fully engaged.

378
00:18:51.640 --> 00:18:55.220
So you wanna have an open stance, you
wanna face the person you're talking to.

379
00:18:55.220 --> 00:18:58.240
Or someone at the board,
you're at a meeting and someone's talking,

380
00:18:58.240 --> 00:19:01.210
you wanna turn your chair and
look at them and engage them.

381
00:19:01.210 --> 00:19:03.760
You wanna have a pleasant
facial expression.

382
00:19:03.760 --> 00:19:07.030
A smile, you don't wanna, yeah, all the
time and scare them and freak them out.

383
00:19:07.030 --> 00:19:08.450
You wanna make good eye contact.

384
00:19:08.450 --> 00:19:11.190
Again, you don't wanna stare them down but
you wanna look at them.

385
00:19:11.190 --> 00:19:13.190
And if it's uncomfortable
to look at someone's face,

386
00:19:13.190 --> 00:19:16.260
you can look down every five,
six, ten seconds.

387
00:19:16.260 --> 00:19:18.400
Of if you don't wanna look
them directly in the eyes,

388
00:19:18.400 --> 00:19:20.870
you just look in the middle of their eyes,
or at their chin or something.

389
00:19:20.870 --> 00:19:24.150
They can't tell, but you wanna make
sure that you're making eye contact.

390
00:19:24.150 --> 00:19:27.460
And when you're with a group, you wanna
make eye contact with one person while

391
00:19:27.460 --> 00:19:29.640
they're talking, and
then maybe look over to another person,

392
00:19:29.640 --> 00:19:32.240
make eye contact with them to
see if they're listening and

393
00:19:32.240 --> 00:19:35.540
things like that to bring
the whole group in.

394
00:19:35.540 --> 00:19:39.120
The next thing is to lean in slightly
to show that you're engaged.

395
00:19:39.120 --> 00:19:41.560
Cuz if you're sitting way back and
you're just sorta looking,

396
00:19:41.560 --> 00:19:45.610
even if you're making eye contact, you're
smiling, I look like I'm not engaged.

397
00:19:45.610 --> 00:19:47.600
I look like I'm not excited.

398
00:19:47.600 --> 00:19:52.260
And then you'll wanna use some other
non-verbal cues like head nodding.

399
00:19:52.260 --> 00:19:53.080
Make it a good point.

400
00:19:53.080 --> 00:19:54.400
So let's put this together.

401
00:19:54.400 --> 00:19:55.670
I'm talking to someone in a meeting.

402
00:19:55.670 --> 00:19:57.420
I'm one on one with them.

403
00:19:57.420 --> 00:19:58.662
They're chatting with me.

404
00:19:58.662 --> 00:20:03.550
I wanna walk in that, stand or
sit facing them, lean in so

405
00:20:03.550 --> 00:20:05.120
it shows I'm paying attention.

406
00:20:05.120 --> 00:20:07.670
Smile and make good gestures and
head nods.

407
00:20:07.670 --> 00:20:08.880
Take notes.

408
00:20:08.880 --> 00:20:13.740
Make good eye contact and show them
that I brought my whole self here.

409
00:20:13.740 --> 00:20:14.690
You're important to me.

410
00:20:14.690 --> 00:20:16.140
You're the most important
thing in the world right now.

411
00:20:16.140 --> 00:20:20.220
You're talking, I've got total focus on
you, I'm looking at you, I'm engaged,

412
00:20:20.220 --> 00:20:21.320
I'm writing notes.

413
00:20:21.320 --> 00:20:24.440
Your message is important,
please keep talking.

414
00:20:24.440 --> 00:20:27.420
Now let's look at the other side
with negative body language.

415
00:20:27.420 --> 00:20:29.180
There's a lot of elements to this.

416
00:20:29.180 --> 00:20:31.399
A lot of people say if someone's
got their arms crossed,

417
00:20:32.450 --> 00:20:33.830
they've got negative body language.

418
00:20:33.830 --> 00:20:35.690
Not always the truth, they might be cold.

419
00:20:35.690 --> 00:20:37.520
They might just be comfortable that way.

420
00:20:37.520 --> 00:20:39.490
But an interesting thing
with body language,

421
00:20:39.490 --> 00:20:43.670
Peter, is the fact that you can't
pull it all just from one gesture.

422
00:20:43.670 --> 00:20:45.923
You gotta sort of read it like a book.

423
00:20:45.923 --> 00:20:46.930
It's not just the one page.

424
00:20:46.930 --> 00:20:49.510
So they got their arms crossed,
they're unhappy.

425
00:20:49.510 --> 00:20:54.006
Maybe, maybe not, but when you see here,
arms crossed, body turned away.

426
00:20:54.006 --> 00:20:55.090
I'm talking to Peter.

427
00:20:55.090 --> 00:20:56.510
But I've got my body turned away.

428
00:20:56.510 --> 00:20:58.930
I'm looking at my watch or
I'm checking my email.

429
00:20:58.930 --> 00:21:01.600
I'm distracted, I'm nodding my head.

430
00:21:01.600 --> 00:21:03.460
But I got a bad facial expression.

431
00:21:03.460 --> 00:21:05.640
There's a big difference between and.

432
00:21:07.130 --> 00:21:09.850
And if I look across and someone's got,
they're shaking their head no,

433
00:21:09.850 --> 00:21:12.340
got a bad thing, and
they're looking at their computer,

434
00:21:12.340 --> 00:21:16.490
they're looking at their watch, they're
looking out the window, I have lost them.

435
00:21:16.490 --> 00:21:20.242
They are not paying, if they're playing
with their glasses or something,

436
00:21:20.242 --> 00:21:22.363
they're looking through their glasses.

437
00:21:22.363 --> 00:21:23.755
>> What?
>> Obviously, I'm not paying attention.

438
00:21:23.755 --> 00:21:24.500
>> I'm sorry, go on.

439
00:21:24.500 --> 00:21:25.930
>> [LAUGH] Got him right there.

440
00:21:25.930 --> 00:21:28.730
Now he just makes a good point.

441
00:21:28.730 --> 00:21:29.790
I was teasing with him.

442
00:21:29.790 --> 00:21:31.920
But if someone takes their
glasses to clean them real quick,

443
00:21:31.920 --> 00:21:34.100
puts them on and
re-engages you immediately like Peter did,

444
00:21:34.100 --> 00:21:36.830
thank you, I know they were
just cleaning their glasses.

445
00:21:36.830 --> 00:21:39.260
But if they're spinning their
glasses through the thing and

446
00:21:39.260 --> 00:21:44.180
they're cleaning them for five or
six minutes, I've lost them, they're gone.

447
00:21:44.180 --> 00:21:45.720
I won't go into this in any more depth.

448
00:21:45.720 --> 00:21:46.650
There's a lot more stuff.

449
00:21:46.650 --> 00:21:47.480
You guys know what it looks.

450
00:21:47.480 --> 00:21:48.940
But here's the point.

451
00:21:48.940 --> 00:21:53.300
The vast majority of people do not
monitor their own body language.

452
00:21:53.300 --> 00:21:54.590
They don't think about it.

453
00:21:54.590 --> 00:21:57.520
They don't make an effort to improve it.

454
00:21:57.520 --> 00:22:00.120
They don't catch themselves
when they're doing it poorly.

455
00:22:00.120 --> 00:22:01.702
>> So an excellent communicator.

456
00:22:01.702 --> 00:22:03.345
And especially think about this on a team.

457
00:22:03.345 --> 00:22:06.620
There's only five or six other,
ten people you're communicating with, you

458
00:22:06.620 --> 00:22:11.390
can not afford to look disengaged, like
you don't care, like you're not listening.

459
00:22:11.390 --> 00:22:14.880
You gotta look like you're there and
you gotta actually be there.

460
00:22:14.880 --> 00:22:20.410
So monitor every now and then,
stop and look at yourself from above.

461
00:22:20.410 --> 00:22:22.870
Go to the balcony, look down and
say, what do I look like?

462
00:22:22.870 --> 00:22:24.410
Am I leaning in, am I smiling?

463
00:22:24.410 --> 00:22:26.850
Am I head nodding, am I taking notes?

464
00:22:26.850 --> 00:22:28.780
Am I making eye contact
with people at table?

465
00:22:28.780 --> 00:22:31.370
And if not, catch yourself and fix it.

466
00:22:31.370 --> 00:22:35.030
Because most people,
the vast majority of people, again, sit or

467
00:22:35.030 --> 00:22:41.070
talk without any thinking about what
signal am I sending with my body language?

468
00:22:41.070 --> 00:22:43.840
And because of that they can
send a very negative signal,

469
00:22:43.840 --> 00:22:46.820
even though they truly do care and
they want to be engaged.

470
00:22:46.820 --> 00:22:48.220
They just don't look engaged.

471
00:22:48.220 --> 00:22:51.430
>> Yeah, I think that's a great point
because most people aren't aware of

472
00:22:51.430 --> 00:22:52.400
this like you said.

473
00:22:52.400 --> 00:22:54.907
And if you were just crossing
your arms because you're cold or

474
00:22:54.907 --> 00:22:57.472
you're looking away because
something happened over there.

475
00:22:57.472 --> 00:22:59.420
You're cleaning your glasses.

476
00:22:59.420 --> 00:23:00.390
That might be fine to you,

477
00:23:00.390 --> 00:23:04.160
but you've gotta remember how other people
are perceiving the things you're doing.

478
00:23:04.160 --> 00:23:07.510
So it's good to be aware of what those
things are so you know how that works.

479
00:23:07.510 --> 00:23:10.000
So what are some other
topics we should cover here?

480
00:23:10.000 --> 00:23:13.290
>> And we're digging in pretty deep here,
Peter.

481
00:23:13.290 --> 00:23:16.000
The next thing I wanna talk
about is social styles.

482
00:23:16.000 --> 00:23:20.450
And many of you watching this might have
been through social styles training.

483
00:23:20.450 --> 00:23:21.630
Not everybody has.

484
00:23:21.630 --> 00:23:22.790
And I'll give you a quick overview.

485
00:23:22.790 --> 00:23:26.030
There's, the way I,
they call it a disk profile, many people.

486
00:23:26.030 --> 00:23:28.120
But I use it slightly different.

487
00:23:28.120 --> 00:23:30.520
I use d as in a driver.

488
00:23:30.520 --> 00:23:34.200
And that's someone who
likes to talk a lot and

489
00:23:34.200 --> 00:23:37.230
it doesn't really care all
that much about people.

490
00:23:37.230 --> 00:23:40.660
So they like to give orders and they
don't have a strong personal connection.

491
00:23:41.820 --> 00:23:45.390
A driver is someone that when you're
communicating with them, wants facts.

492
00:23:45.390 --> 00:23:49.965
They want bullet points,
they want it quick, they want information.

493
00:23:49.965 --> 00:23:53.173
They just want the most important
information, the essential information.

494
00:23:53.173 --> 00:23:57.302
If you come to a driver and
you're trying to give a big explanation,

495
00:23:57.302 --> 00:23:59.411
bring him a stack of data that big.

496
00:23:59.411 --> 00:24:02.280
You are speaking in a language
they don't understand.

497
00:24:02.280 --> 00:24:06.880
You're communicating with them in
a way that they are not comfortable.

498
00:24:06.880 --> 00:24:11.020
So the idea here is, if you're with
a driver, you've gotta bring them short

499
00:24:11.020 --> 00:24:13.870
stuff, couple of pages,
bullet points, you gotta be quick,

500
00:24:13.870 --> 00:24:17.610
you gotta get to the point quick, you
gotta move on, and make a decision fast.

501
00:24:17.610 --> 00:24:21.420
That's what a driver wants, and as I'm
explaining these think about what you are.

502
00:24:21.420 --> 00:24:24.110
Think about how you like communication,
so driver is one.

503
00:24:24.110 --> 00:24:26.120
The next one is expressive.

504
00:24:26.120 --> 00:24:30.580
An expressive someone that likes to
talk and likes to be around people.

505
00:24:30.580 --> 00:24:33.580
Actually they like to be
the center of attention.

506
00:24:33.580 --> 00:24:36.340
They're the person that the driver
just wants to get stuff done.

507
00:24:36.340 --> 00:24:38.215
The expressive says,
how will it make me look?

508
00:24:38.215 --> 00:24:42.360
[LAUGH] If it will make me look good,
then I'm all on board.

509
00:24:42.360 --> 00:24:44.970
Expressive doesn't need
a ton of information.

510
00:24:44.970 --> 00:24:47.500
They just need to know,
how will it impact them?

511
00:24:47.500 --> 00:24:48.720
Will it make them look good?

512
00:24:48.720 --> 00:24:52.690
Will it or put them at risk and
potentially make them look bad?

513
00:24:52.690 --> 00:24:56.070
An expressive is usually highly motivated,
excited.

514
00:24:56.070 --> 00:24:58.920
So they're the kind of person that,
passion and

515
00:24:58.920 --> 00:25:02.080
excitement and motivation communication
really resonates with them

516
00:25:02.080 --> 00:25:04.038
because they like to get
pumped up about stuff.

517
00:25:04.038 --> 00:25:05.750
They're slow to make a decision.

518
00:25:05.750 --> 00:25:08.670
When you give them information
until they figure it out,

519
00:25:08.670 --> 00:25:11.140
how it will make them look,
how it will impact them.

520
00:25:11.140 --> 00:25:12.450
That's your expressive.

521
00:25:12.450 --> 00:25:14.400
Next one is called the amiable.

522
00:25:14.400 --> 00:25:16.771
And the amiable is someone who
doesn't like to talk a lot but

523
00:25:16.771 --> 00:25:18.059
cares a lot about other people.

524
00:25:18.059 --> 00:25:23.494
This is about, in most organizations,
about 60% of the workforce.

525
00:25:23.494 --> 00:25:28.265
But if you go into like medical or
healthcare or something like that, or

526
00:25:28.265 --> 00:25:31.286
social work, it spikes up to 80 to 90%,

527
00:25:31.286 --> 00:25:37.455
because these are folks that really
care about the team above anything else.

528
00:25:37.455 --> 00:25:40.390
They're the ones that you need to bring
them information about how will it

529
00:25:40.390 --> 00:25:41.880
impact the team.

530
00:25:41.880 --> 00:25:43.372
They are not as worried
about themselves but

531
00:25:43.372 --> 00:25:46.130
they're very worried about how everyone,
what everybody else thinks.

532
00:25:46.130 --> 00:25:47.150
How theyll be impacted?

533
00:25:47.150 --> 00:25:48.560
Whats going on with them?

534
00:25:48.560 --> 00:25:54.440
So, when youre communicating with a high
amiable, you got make them comfortable.

535
00:25:54.440 --> 00:25:55.650
That its good for the team,

536
00:25:55.650 --> 00:25:59.110
its good for all of us,
its gonna be a win for all of us.

537
00:25:59.110 --> 00:26:02.780
An expressive likes all
the attention on them.

538
00:26:02.780 --> 00:26:06.370
We're going to win an award from the boss,
from the CEO.

539
00:26:06.370 --> 00:26:08.970
The amiable doesn't want
the personal attention.

540
00:26:08.970 --> 00:26:11.700
Our team will win an award.

541
00:26:11.700 --> 00:26:16.580
You will not motivate or communicate well
with an amiable if you say you're going to

542
00:26:16.580 --> 00:26:20.170
do this, you're in charge of it, you'll
get all the credit, you have to, you're

543
00:26:20.170 --> 00:26:23.930
going to have to tell other people on the
team what to do, it doesn't work so good.

544
00:26:23.930 --> 00:26:25.562
And the last one is the analytic.

545
00:26:25.562 --> 00:26:28.400
And the analytic is someone
who doesn't ask questions and

546
00:26:28.400 --> 00:26:30.560
doesn't really interact with people,
they interact with data.

547
00:26:31.980 --> 00:26:34.890
They're always looking for
the right answer.

548
00:26:34.890 --> 00:26:37.020
The driver wants an answer fast.

549
00:26:37.020 --> 00:26:39.620
The expressive wants an answer
that makes them look good.

550
00:26:39.620 --> 00:26:41.710
The amiable wants an answer
that makes everybody happy.

551
00:26:41.710 --> 00:26:45.690
The analytic wants the answer
that's right and correct and

552
00:26:45.690 --> 00:26:47.530
has all the right numbers on it.

553
00:26:47.530 --> 00:26:50.177
So when you are dealing with
someone who's highly analytical,

554
00:26:50.177 --> 00:26:52.588
you need to bring them lots of data,
lots of information.

555
00:26:52.588 --> 00:26:56.290
You need to back up what you say
with research and other things.

556
00:26:56.290 --> 00:26:59.240
Because they need to know that I've
got all the information I need to

557
00:26:59.240 --> 00:27:00.170
make a good decision.

558
00:27:01.230 --> 00:27:02.730
So two things here.

559
00:27:02.730 --> 00:27:06.450
Number one, think about this
with everyone else on your team.

560
00:27:06.450 --> 00:27:09.430
And people ask me all the time,
what's the best communication style?

561
00:27:09.430 --> 00:27:11.840
Here it is, the person you can flex.

562
00:27:11.840 --> 00:27:16.210
The person who looks around their team and
says Peter is an amiable.

563
00:27:16.210 --> 00:27:17.130
And when I talk to him and

564
00:27:17.130 --> 00:27:21.610
give him information, I need to talk about
the team, about us, ask about his family,

565
00:27:21.610 --> 00:27:25.430
see how things are going and connect with
him personally, and make him feel safe.

566
00:27:25.430 --> 00:27:27.170
John is a driver.

567
00:27:27.170 --> 00:27:28.390
John doesn't wanna waste time.

568
00:27:28.390 --> 00:27:31.870
John wants four bullet points, and
boom, let's move on the agenda,

569
00:27:31.870 --> 00:27:33.710
let's move on the agenda,
next, next, next, next.

570
00:27:35.340 --> 00:27:37.010
Might have somebody
that's highly analytical.

571
00:27:37.010 --> 00:27:39.360
And by the way you need all
these people on your team,

572
00:27:39.360 --> 00:27:43.340
because if you don't have an analytic, you
don't have anybody checking your facts.

573
00:27:43.340 --> 00:27:45.630
And if you don't have an amiable,
everybody is fighting.

574
00:27:45.630 --> 00:27:49.940
I've worked with law teams where
everyone's a driver and it ain't pretty.

575
00:27:49.940 --> 00:27:53.680
So step one is, what is everybody else
on your team, and being able to flex and

576
00:27:53.680 --> 00:27:54.750
adjust your style to them.

577
00:27:54.750 --> 00:27:58.140
And then two, taking a hard look in
the mirror and saying, what am I?

578
00:27:58.140 --> 00:28:02.860
How can I flex, and also let me share
with the other people on my team

579
00:28:02.860 --> 00:28:06.503
what social style I am so
they know how I like to give information.

580
00:28:07.560 --> 00:28:11.270
Years ago I had an assistant that worked
for me when I was running a large company.

581
00:28:11.270 --> 00:28:14.100
When I'm running a company,
I'm a driver, driver, driver.

582
00:28:14.100 --> 00:28:16.000
She was full amiable.

583
00:28:16.000 --> 00:28:19.446
I would come in the morning and say,
I do, a, b, c, d and I need them by noon,

584
00:28:19.446 --> 00:28:22.640
and she'd go,
don't you wanna ask about my family?

585
00:28:22.640 --> 00:28:27.350
And it wasn't until I realized that if I
didn't communicate in a style that was

586
00:28:27.350 --> 00:28:28.190
comfortable for her,

587
00:28:28.190 --> 00:28:32.030
it was basically like I was yelling
at her in a foreign language.

588
00:28:32.030 --> 00:28:35.830
And if you want your team to work well,
and I said this earlier,

589
00:28:35.830 --> 00:28:40.440
the responsibility for
effective communication is always on you.

590
00:28:41.658 --> 00:28:44.850
If they didn't understand you, if you
gave them the information the wrong way,

591
00:28:44.850 --> 00:28:46.710
if you didn't match their social style and

592
00:28:46.710 --> 00:28:50.090
they don't understand,
that is your fault, not theirs.

593
00:28:50.090 --> 00:28:51.625
Which is why this takes so much work.

594
00:28:51.625 --> 00:28:56.930
>> Sure, that, I think, helps us really
understand effective communication,

595
00:28:56.930 --> 00:28:58.120
but now let's kind of shift gears and

00:28:58.120 --> 00:29:01.640
talk about how we can turn
that into collaboration.

597
00:29:01.640 --> 00:29:05.410
>> Well, there's a couple of different
things to talk about with collaboration.

598
00:29:05.410 --> 00:29:09.052
And the first thing I want to do is
briefly review again what we talked about

599
00:29:09.052 --> 00:29:12.519
the very first session, when we were
talking about launching a team,

600
00:29:12.519 --> 00:29:15.950
is what level of collaboration
is expected from the team?

601
00:29:15.950 --> 00:29:18.140
Not all teams are highly collaborative.

602
00:29:18.140 --> 00:29:21.380
You've got some teams and
there was three levels if you recall.

603
00:29:21.380 --> 00:29:24.300
There was the team where
everyone's independent.

604
00:29:25.570 --> 00:29:29.670
I'm on the team, supposedly,
but my work is my own,

605
00:29:29.670 --> 00:29:32.050
I work on my own time,
I create my own work product.

606
00:29:32.050 --> 00:29:33.240
Then I hand it in.

607
00:29:33.240 --> 00:29:35.730
And my work becomes apart
of the team's work.

00:29:35.730 --> 00:29:38.160
And I use sports analogies for

609
00:29:38.160 --> 00:29:39.950
That's like a golf team.

610
00:29:39.950 --> 00:29:42.240
It's me versus the course,
no one else can help me.

611
00:29:42.240 --> 00:29:44.700
I can have the highest score and
I can do great but the team can lose.

612
00:29:44.700 --> 00:29:46.530
That's an independent team.

613
00:29:46.530 --> 00:29:50.560
Level two is an interdependent team, where
we're working together a little bit but

614
00:29:50.560 --> 00:29:51.700
we're also working apart.

615
00:29:51.700 --> 00:29:54.470
I think you would see this

616
00:29:54.470 --> 00:29:57.340
Where we're not always together,
we're working independently but

617
00:29:57.340 --> 00:30:00.910
all of our stuff comes together and
the team, sorry.
