00:30:00.910 --> 00:30:03.730
Sometimes I'm depending on
other people on the team,

619
00:30:03.730 --> 00:30:05.580
sometimes I'm working independently.

620
00:30:05.580 --> 00:30:08.110
Again, the sports analogy, baseball team.

621
00:30:08.110 --> 00:30:11.110
When I'm out in the field I've got
to play with the rest of the team,

622
00:30:11.110 --> 00:30:14.340
I've got to help them, I've got to catch
the ball, throw it in, do all that, but

623
00:30:14.340 --> 00:30:17.530
when I'm at the plate It's
just me versus the pitcher.

624
00:30:17.530 --> 00:30:18.810
Nobody else can help me.

625
00:30:18.810 --> 00:30:21.720
So interdependent teams where
sometimes I'm working alone,

626
00:30:21.720 --> 00:30:25.390
sometimes I'm working in a team,
and we're helping each other.

627
00:30:25.390 --> 00:30:31.530
The last one, which is what most real,
true teams are, is a dependent team.

628
00:30:31.530 --> 00:30:34.870
And a dependent team is
where everybody's work

629
00:30:34.870 --> 00:30:39.010
is connected to everybody else's work,
where it's one group output.

630
00:30:39.010 --> 00:30:43.160
Where if one person on the team messes
up it impacts everybody else negatively.

631
00:30:43.160 --> 00:30:45.430
And my favorite example,
sports analogy for

632
00:30:45.430 --> 00:30:49.270
that, is a Olympic four
by four track team.

633
00:30:49.270 --> 00:30:53.270
If one of the people on the team
decides they're not gonna run, or

634
00:30:53.270 --> 00:30:57.320
tosses the baton and doesn't pick it up,
the team, the whole team loses.

635
00:30:57.320 --> 00:31:00.440
All four people have to run,
they have to run their fastest, and

636
00:31:00.440 --> 00:31:02.230
they have to run for the finish line.

637
00:31:02.230 --> 00:31:04.150
They're totally dependent on each other.

638
00:31:04.150 --> 00:31:07.300
So before we can even talk
about collaboration on a team,

639
00:31:07.300 --> 00:31:09.720
you need to sit down with your team and
say, what kind of team are we?

640
00:31:09.720 --> 00:31:12.450
Are we even a team or
are we more of a work group?

641
00:31:12.450 --> 00:31:16.500
And adjust the level of collaboration
to what's appropriate for

642
00:31:16.500 --> 00:31:19.790
the kind of team you have.

643
00:31:19.790 --> 00:31:24.260
Now I wanna talk about building a more
collaborative team once you understand it

644
00:31:24.260 --> 00:31:26.750
is a dependent or independent team.

645
00:31:26.750 --> 00:31:28.260
And here's the big idea
with collaboration.

646
00:31:28.260 --> 00:31:32.000
Sort of like extending trust,
we talked about that, you have to do it.

647
00:31:32.000 --> 00:31:36.280
If you want collaboration on the team,
you have to be highly collaborative.

648
00:31:36.280 --> 00:31:38.290
You want to be participatory.

649
00:31:38.290 --> 00:31:40.820
You want to see everybody else
on the team as a partner.

650
00:31:40.820 --> 00:31:45.613
So I've got a few ideas here that you've
gotta do to build high collaboration on

651
00:31:45.613 --> 00:31:46.337
your team.

652
00:31:46.337 --> 00:31:48.101
Couple of first ones.

653
00:31:48.101 --> 00:31:51.253
You've gotta be dependable,
consistent, and supportive.

654
00:31:51.253 --> 00:31:54.264
Dependable, another word I
would use there is reliable.

655
00:31:54.264 --> 00:31:55.888
I can take your word to the bank.

656
00:31:55.888 --> 00:31:59.070
If I'm gonna collaborate with you,
I need to know I can depend on you.

657
00:31:59.070 --> 00:32:01.338
I don't wanna be on a team with
people that don't do what they say

658
00:32:01.338 --> 00:32:02.054
they're gonna do.

659
00:32:02.054 --> 00:32:04.015
So I've gotta be dependable, reliable,

660
00:32:04.015 --> 00:32:08.130
I've also gotta be highly supportive
of the other people on my team.

661
00:32:08.130 --> 00:32:12.270
You can not have a collaborative culture
if people don't care about each other,

662
00:32:12.270 --> 00:32:12.980
help each other,

663
00:32:12.980 --> 00:32:17.990
support each other, celebrate together,
go through difficulties together.

664
00:32:17.990 --> 00:32:20.260
Gotta be supportive to everyone else.

665
00:32:20.260 --> 00:32:23.430
And again, every time it makes
a rumor it starts with you.

666
00:32:23.430 --> 00:32:25.720
If you want the team to be more
collaborative with you, and

667
00:32:25.720 --> 00:32:27.540
you want to create
the collaborative culture,

668
00:32:27.540 --> 00:32:29.870
you're the on who has to be dependable and
supportive.

669
00:32:31.080 --> 00:32:35.890
The big one here is, easy to work with.

670
00:32:35.890 --> 00:32:40.010
Often times on teams we get someone
that doesn't want to play by the rules.

671
00:32:40.010 --> 00:32:42.710
And there is a couple of
different ways to handle this.

672
00:32:42.710 --> 00:32:47.270
First of all, you want people that work
well with other people, that are easy to

673
00:32:47.270 --> 00:32:51.210
work with, they get their work done on
time, and you want to be that person.

674
00:32:51.210 --> 00:32:55.550
You want to go out of your way to not
cause stress, not cause problems,

675
00:32:55.550 --> 00:32:59.790
be straightforward, be transparent,
bring up issues as soon as they arise.

676
00:32:59.790 --> 00:33:03.570
Be the one that holds
the team together and is

677
00:33:03.570 --> 00:33:08.760
the one that fosters lots of collaboration
by helping people work well together.

678
00:33:08.760 --> 00:33:10.430
Now, I'm gonna give you
a little bit other insight.

679
00:33:10.430 --> 00:33:15.030
If you've got somebody on the team
who is not easy to work with.

680
00:33:15.030 --> 00:33:16.970
They're difficult and challenging.

681
00:33:16.970 --> 00:33:18.530
There's a couple of different
ways to handle that.

682
00:33:18.530 --> 00:33:21.450
We're gonna talk about conflict in
a minute and how to handle conflict.

683
00:33:21.450 --> 00:33:23.790
But this is more on a structural basis.

684
00:33:23.790 --> 00:33:25.650
You go to that person and

685
00:33:25.650 --> 00:33:30.710
say, you're on the team, we want you
to get on the team and get involved.

686
00:33:30.710 --> 00:33:31.880
That's a requirement.

687
00:33:31.880 --> 00:33:36.870
No prima donnas, no hanging out in
the corner, no not doing your work.

688
00:33:36.870 --> 00:33:38.690
You gotta be on the team.

689
00:33:38.690 --> 00:33:43.095
If they refuse to do that,
then there's two courses of action.

690
00:33:43.095 --> 00:33:46.781
You can go to the rest of the team and
say, we have somebody, Bill over here

691
00:33:46.781 --> 00:33:50.769
who's exceedingly talented, puts out
great work, does everything on time,

692
00:33:50.769 --> 00:33:54.940
first class work but you don't wanna
have anything to do with the team.

693
00:33:54.940 --> 00:33:58.810
We can depend that his work will be
great and it will be on time but

694
00:33:58.810 --> 00:34:00.110
he doesn't want to come to meetings.

695
00:34:00.110 --> 00:34:03.400
He doesn't wanna do any of the after hour
stuff, doesn't wanna have beer with us.

696
00:34:03.400 --> 00:34:06.860
Does not want any of that he just wants
to do the work and turn it in and

697
00:34:06.860 --> 00:34:09.840
you go to the team and
say are you willing to let that happen.

698
00:34:09.840 --> 00:34:14.540
Are you willing to allow one person on
this team to play outside of the team

699
00:34:14.540 --> 00:34:19.220
rules and sometimes I will tell
you that teams will allow that.

700
00:34:19.220 --> 00:34:23.100
They will say he or she is so
talented has so much experience

701
00:34:23.100 --> 00:34:27.200
brings such quality to the team,
we're willing to let them break the rules.

702
00:34:27.200 --> 00:34:31.240
But all the rest of us know that we're
making that agreement together and

703
00:34:31.240 --> 00:34:34.780
we're not gonna get upset about it or
get frustrated or say it isn't fair,

704
00:34:34.780 --> 00:34:39.210
because we've decided as a team to allow
someone to not follow the team rules.

705
00:34:39.210 --> 00:34:43.210
Andi n the last option is If
they won't get on the team and

706
00:34:43.210 --> 00:34:46.000
play with the team and the rest of the
team says, no, we want them on the team.

707
00:34:46.000 --> 00:34:47.660
We're not going to allow
them to break the rules.

708
00:34:47.660 --> 00:34:50.200
Then, they are typically
removed from the team.

709
00:34:50.200 --> 00:34:54.010
Because if you allow one person on the
team to break the rules, not show up for

710
00:34:54.010 --> 00:34:58.100
meetings, not turn their work in,
have a bad attitude, refuse to cooperate,

711
00:34:58.100 --> 00:35:01.610
as soon as you look the other way and
pretend that's not happening,

712
00:35:01.610 --> 00:35:06.010
you'll find that the whole team ends
up there, and it will destroy the team.

713
00:35:06.010 --> 00:35:09.770
So that was, theres a couple of
more here, I wanted to get to.

714
00:35:11.060 --> 00:35:12.720
Again, you keep your team collaborating,

715
00:35:12.720 --> 00:35:15.600
keep them on that shared goal,
that shared vision.

716
00:35:15.600 --> 00:35:17.030
Makes sure everybody aligned.

717
00:35:17.030 --> 00:35:19.860
Its a lot easier to have
a highly collaborative team

718
00:35:19.860 --> 00:35:21.660
when you all care about where
you are going together.

719
00:35:21.660 --> 00:35:23.820
You understand where you are going
together, youre talking about,

720
00:35:23.820 --> 00:35:25.890
youre supporting,
youre excited about it.

721
00:35:25.890 --> 00:35:30.710
Which leads me to the last one is,
when you get there, celebrate as a team.

722
00:35:30.710 --> 00:35:32.900
Don't sit in your office and go yeah!

723
00:35:32.900 --> 00:35:36.160
Go out and collaborate with the rest
of the team, help each other.

724
00:35:36.160 --> 00:35:38.240
The way I like to say it is,

725
00:35:38.240 --> 00:35:43.230
when there's a challenge, there's
a problem, as a team run to the problem.

726
00:35:43.230 --> 00:35:46.260
Run to the problem, get in there shoulder
to shoulder, roll up your sleeves,

727
00:35:46.260 --> 00:35:50.730
work hard, you know, fix that problem
together as a unit, as a team,

728
00:35:50.730 --> 00:35:55.690
as a highly collaborative group of people,
but when there's a win,

729
00:35:55.690 --> 00:35:59.680
also celebrate as a team and look at each
other and say, we did this together.

730
00:35:59.680 --> 00:36:02.350
We did this cuz we got along,
cuz we shared information.

731
00:36:02.350 --> 00:36:07.330
And you reinforce all of the elements of
collaboration, trust, and teamwork, and

732
00:36:07.330 --> 00:36:11.290
clearly show that because we did those
things, that's why we were successful.

733
00:36:11.290 --> 00:36:13.930
>> All right, John,
you've alluded to it a couple of times,

734
00:36:13.930 --> 00:36:18.810
but what happens if we do have that
team that's just not getting along?

735
00:36:18.810 --> 00:36:22.040
How do we resolve those conflicts?

736
00:36:22.040 --> 00:36:25.890
>> Yeah, there's a lot of work that's
been done around how to handle conflict,

737
00:36:25.890 --> 00:36:29.810
and there's a couple of models, and
there's one that I like very much.

738
00:36:29.810 --> 00:36:32.030
I believe it came from the book
Difficult Conversations.

739
00:36:32.030 --> 00:36:33.910
It was that or Crucial Conversations.

740
00:36:33.910 --> 00:36:35.820
I recommend both of them because, again,

741
00:36:35.820 --> 00:36:40.350
much like communication Peter, very rarely
are we taught how to handle conflict.

742
00:36:40.350 --> 00:36:43.440
Matter of fact I believe that
communication skills and

743
00:36:43.440 --> 00:36:48.300
conflict resolution skills should me
mandatory in high school and college.

744
00:36:48.300 --> 00:36:51.000
Cuz these are two skills that
if you don't learn them early,

745
00:36:52.000 --> 00:36:55.330
you're setting yourself up for
some pain later on in your life.

746
00:36:55.330 --> 00:36:56.910
And these are not skills most people have,

747
00:36:56.910 --> 00:37:01.410
so let's look at what I call
the five levels of confrontation.

748
00:37:01.410 --> 00:37:04.700
So you and I aren't getting along,
we have a little bit of an argument.

749
00:37:04.700 --> 00:37:07.360
Level one, let me just listen to you.

750
00:37:07.360 --> 00:37:08.500
I'm not gonna interrupt you.

751
00:37:08.500 --> 00:37:10.190
I'm not gonna say anything.

752
00:37:10.190 --> 00:37:14.430
I would like to understand from your point
of view, exactly what you're upset about,

753
00:37:14.430 --> 00:37:17.810
how you feel, what's wrong,
and I'm not gonna say a word,

754
00:37:17.810 --> 00:37:21.350
I'm just gonna sit here and listen to you.

755
00:37:21.350 --> 00:37:23.010
How often in your life
does that happen to you?

756
00:37:23.010 --> 00:37:24.540
[LAUGH]
>> Not very often at all.

757
00:37:24.540 --> 00:37:27.150
>> Not very often, no you don't
get a lot of people to say that.

758
00:37:27.150 --> 00:37:29.270
If you can just to learn this one skill,

759
00:37:29.270 --> 00:37:31.990
to say I can see that
things aren't going well.

760
00:37:31.990 --> 00:37:33.520
We're both starting to get a little angry.

761
00:37:33.520 --> 00:37:36.660
Let me just stop right here and
I wanna sit and listen to you.

762
00:37:36.660 --> 00:37:37.840
If you learn to just do this one thing,

763
00:37:37.840 --> 00:37:41.480
you'd probably be in the top 10% of
people that handle conflict well.

764
00:37:41.480 --> 00:37:44.860
And it's usually not an hour of them
talking, it's a minute, or two, or three,

765
00:37:44.860 --> 00:37:45.790
or five.

766
00:37:45.790 --> 00:37:49.080
And very often they talk
themselves out of being mad.

767
00:37:49.080 --> 00:37:52.390
They realize it was a misconception,
something they didn't think through or

768
00:37:52.390 --> 00:37:55.900
they start to explain it to themselves and
it diffuses the situation.

769
00:37:55.900 --> 00:37:58.160
Level one, listen don't interrupt.

770
00:37:58.160 --> 00:38:02.440
Level two, another skill that very
few people get taught, I statements.

771
00:38:02.440 --> 00:38:04.060
What an I statement says is,

772
00:38:04.060 --> 00:38:07.190
let me tell you from my point
of view how I see things.

773
00:38:09.380 --> 00:38:11.670
I'll use this great one for
married couples.

774
00:38:11.670 --> 00:38:13.540
I'm not taking out the trash.

775
00:38:13.540 --> 00:38:17.680
Instead of getting mad, you say, from my
point of view, when you don't take out

776
00:38:17.680 --> 00:38:21.410
the trash, it feels to me like
you don't care about me and

777
00:38:21.410 --> 00:38:24.350
you don't respect me as a partner and
I don't feel loved.

778
00:38:24.350 --> 00:38:26.846
Now that's sounds like a lot of stuff but

779
00:38:26.846 --> 00:38:31.336
that's often how people feel in
a marriage or when you turn things late.

780
00:38:31.336 --> 00:38:36.770
When you come to meetings late from my
point of view it feels disrespectful.

781
00:38:36.770 --> 00:38:39.540
Feels like you don't care about he rest
of the team and you don't care about us.

782
00:38:39.540 --> 00:38:41.210
But that's just how I see it.

783
00:38:41.210 --> 00:38:43.350
That may not be how it is,
but that's how I see it.

784
00:38:43.350 --> 00:38:46.657
Now the reason it's so important to go
back to that I statement is because if you

785
00:38:46.657 --> 00:38:49.530
say, when you come to me this late,
you're being disrespectful.

786
00:38:49.530 --> 00:38:50.640
What does the other person say?

787
00:38:50.640 --> 00:38:51.490
No, I'm not.

788
00:38:51.490 --> 00:38:52.400
Yes, you are.

789
00:38:52.400 --> 00:38:53.100
No, I'm not.

790
00:38:53.100 --> 00:38:54.000
I'm not disrespectful.

791
00:38:54.000 --> 00:38:54.510
Yes.

792
00:38:54.510 --> 00:38:58.690
And you get into an argument, because
I'm pointing the finger at you, you are.

793
00:38:58.690 --> 00:39:03.610
The I statement says I feel,
I see, I think, my point of view.

794
00:39:03.610 --> 00:39:05.590
Someone can't see that when
you come to the meetings late,

795
00:39:05.590 --> 00:39:07.310
I feel like you're being disrespectful.

796
00:39:07.310 --> 00:39:08.070
I'm not.

797
00:39:08.070 --> 00:39:09.460
I didn't say you were.

798
00:39:09.460 --> 00:39:11.360
What I said is, I feel that way.

799
00:39:11.360 --> 00:39:13.790
It feels to me like you
don't care about the team.

800
00:39:13.790 --> 00:39:15.420
You can't argue with
someone else's feelings.

801
00:39:15.420 --> 00:39:17.380
You can tell them they shouldn't
feel that way, and again you say,

802
00:39:17.380 --> 00:39:20.370
well, I probably shouldn't,
but that is how I feel.

803
00:39:20.370 --> 00:39:22.480
And I just wanted to share
my feelings with you.

804
00:39:22.480 --> 00:39:23.560
So, level one,

805
00:39:23.560 --> 00:39:26.940
let me listen to you without interrupting
you at all, til I understand you.

806
00:39:26.940 --> 00:39:32.380
Level two, let me tell you how I feel
from my point of view, how I see things.

807
00:39:32.380 --> 00:39:35.280
I'm not attacking you,
I'm just sharing my opinion, my ideas,

808
00:39:35.280 --> 00:39:37.530
my thoughts, my feelings.

809
00:39:37.530 --> 00:39:40.100
Level three is what I call negotiation,
okay?

810
00:39:40.100 --> 00:39:43.130
I've listened to you
I've told you how I feel.

811
00:39:43.130 --> 00:39:44.290
We don't agree.

812
00:39:44.290 --> 00:39:46.800
Can we agree to disagree agreeably?

813
00:39:46.800 --> 00:39:49.280
Can we sit down and talk this through?

814
00:39:49.280 --> 00:39:53.121
And this is where we hope that
most conflicts would be fixed.

815
00:39:53.121 --> 00:39:57.658
A simple discussion between two people
who are collaborating on a team together,

816
00:39:57.658 --> 00:40:02.129
who respect each other That are partners
on the team, having a mature discussion

817
00:40:02.129 --> 00:40:06.440
about a difference of opinion, and
negotiating a win-win outcome.

818
00:40:06.440 --> 00:40:08.950
I'll do this for you, you do this for
me, I'll stop doing this,

819
00:40:08.950 --> 00:40:10.810
I'll start turning stuff in on time.

820
00:40:10.810 --> 00:40:12.010
I apologize, are we good?

821
00:40:12.010 --> 00:40:14.100
Everything's great, let's move forward.

822
00:40:14.100 --> 00:40:15.080
That's level three.

823
00:40:15.080 --> 00:40:19.110
If that doesn't work, we're attempting
to negotiate and things escalate.

824
00:40:19.110 --> 00:40:20.810
And we're not getting to win-win.

825
00:40:20.810 --> 00:40:24.000
It's look towards going towards
to lose-win or lose-lose.

826
00:40:24.000 --> 00:40:27.698
Let me go to level four which
is gentle confrontation.

827
00:40:27.698 --> 00:40:31.938
And what gentle confrontation says is,
I've listened to you,

828
00:40:31.938 --> 00:40:34.774
I believe I understand your point of view.

829
00:40:34.774 --> 00:40:37.203
I've told you how I feel
from my point of view.

830
00:40:37.203 --> 00:40:40.070
We've discussed this and
we can't come to an agreement.

831
00:40:40.070 --> 00:40:42.010
Here's the gentle confrontation.

832
00:40:42.010 --> 00:40:45.695
It would really be wonderful if
you would think this through and

833
00:40:45.695 --> 00:40:48.475
change your position,
because if you don't,

834
00:40:48.475 --> 00:40:52.941
it could have some serious ramifications
to the team and nobody wants that.

835
00:40:52.941 --> 00:40:55.401
So it would sound like this,
I listened to you,

836
00:40:55.401 --> 00:40:59.719
I understand you're under a lot of stress,
you've got a lot of projects going on.

837
00:40:59.719 --> 00:41:04.409
From my point of view, when you turn work
in days late it impacts the whole team,

838
00:41:04.409 --> 00:41:08.399
it's stressful for me, I feel stressed,
I feel uncomfortable and

839
00:41:08.399 --> 00:41:11.487
I feel angry at you and
I don't want to feel that way.

840
00:41:11.487 --> 00:41:16.041
I've asked you to please get things in
on time and if you don't it's gonna pull

841
00:41:16.041 --> 00:41:20.664
the whole team down and we're all gonna
fail and I don't want that to happen, so

842
00:41:20.664 --> 00:41:25.043
would you please try in the future to
get all of your assignments in on time.

843
00:41:25.043 --> 00:41:28.590
I heard you, here's my point of view,
we can't come to an agreement.

844
00:41:28.590 --> 00:41:32.390
I would really like it if you would
decide to do what I need you to do.

845
00:41:33.390 --> 00:41:36.713
If that doesn't work, then you go
to the fifth and final final level

846

episodes.description: You will begin the session with a clear definition of motivation and how to create it for an individual. 00:09:55.850 --> 00:09:59.690

172
00:09:59.690 --> 00:10:01.290

173
00:10:01.290 --> 00:10:06.092
Peter, to senior executives and I'll

00:10:23.300 --> 00:10:26.406
So a big suggestion I have here

180
00:10:28.030 --> 00:10:32.470
That leads me to one more thing,

181
00:10:33.880 --> 00:10:38.070
Again, if I ask people do you have

182
00:10:38.070 --> 00:10:41.710
not for anybody else, not society,
not what anybody else told you to do,

183
00:10:41.710 --> 00:10:45.780

00:10:45.780 --> 00:10:46.905
What would have to happen?

00:10:46.905 --> 00:10:48.510
What would you have to have, do, be?

00:10:49.520 --> 00:10:50.890
What would have to happen in your life for

00:10:50.890 --> 00:10:54.300

00:11:07.930 --> 00:11:10.867

00:11:26.520 --> 00:11:28.150
Again, you put that with purpose,

00:11:28.150 --> 00:11:31.330

>> We're starting to get to a place here

00:12:29.000 --> 00:12:33.290

00:12:33.290 --> 00:12:35.650
And I've written a few notes here.

00:12:35.650 --> 00:12:37.930
And I'm gonna say this

00:12:37.930 --> 00:12:42.930
This comes from a big Harvard research,

00:12:42.930 --> 00:12:47.910

00:12:47.910 --> 00:12:54.350
a sharply focused, compelling, and
well-communicated vision and strategy.

227
00:12:54.350 --> 00:12:57.140
If I'm gonna optimize my team,
I have to sit down and

what does it look like,

00:13:23.540 --> 00:13:26.010
If people are guessing at

00:13:26.010 --> 00:13:29.260
this is not an optimized situation.

00:13:29.260 --> 00:13:33.740
So underneath that you've got

238
00:13:33.740 --> 00:13:36.630

what's our major goals,

00:13:36.630 --> 00:13:39.910
what are the tactics we're gonna

big thing figure out what to say no to.

245
00:13:57.630 --> 00:14:00.750

246
00:14:00.750 --> 00:14:03.650
They're focusing on parts of the project

247
00:14:03.650 --> 00:14:06.380

to the overall project.

248
00:14:06.380 --> 00:14:10.480
And taking away all that extra knowledge,
time, energy,

249
00:14:10.480 --> 00:14:15.170
effort, money and wasting it on things

250
00:14:15.170 --> 00:14:19.160
As part of that, and we've talked

251
00:14:19.160 --> 00:14:22.520
you can't have that level of focus

without people understanding where

253
00:14:25.830 --> 00:14:28.610
So the idea again of track and post.

254
00:14:28.610 --> 00:14:32.556
If I'm gonna have a highly optimized team,
I gotta know where everyone on the team

00:14:32.556 --> 00:14:35.757

where the rest of the team stands,

256
00:14:35.757 --> 00:14:39.699
how we're all doing on our goal, what
the timeline is, how things are measured,

257
00:14:39.699 --> 00:14:41.954
what we're moving towards towards success.

258
00:14:41.954 --> 00:14:46.288

binary goals that are clear, unambiguous,

259
00:14:46.288 --> 00:14:48.911
no guessing and
that everybody can look at everyday.

260
00:14:48.911 --> 00:14:52.062
So if they start to slip off track,
they start to get sub-optimal,

261
00:14:52.062 --> 00:14:55.156

say here's where we got to fix it,

262
00:14:55.156 --> 00:14:58.528
here is where the bottleneck is,
here is where things are slowing down,

263
00:14:58.528 --> 00:15:01.990
this is what we need to focus on,
here is where the project needs to go now.

264
00:15:03.260 --> 00:15:05.810
To keep that level of
communication in focus,

265
00:15:05.810 --> 00:15:11.690
you gotta have a lot of team meetings,
spend time together, always looking to

266
00:15:11.690 --> 00:15:16.700
the level of competence and
involvement and expertise on the team.

267
00:15:16.700 --> 00:15:21.250
Another thing that happens with poorly
optimized teams is I take someone who

268
00:15:21.250 --> 00:15:24.830
doesn't have a lot of experience and put
them on top of a project they have never

269
00:15:24.830 --> 00:15:28.340
done before, when someone else on the team

270
00:15:28.340 --> 00:15:30.980
this is not a good use of talent and
resources.

271
00:15:30.980 --> 00:15:37.220
So, backing up and constantly
monitoring how is the team doing?

272
00:15:37.220 --> 00:15:39.080
Or do we have people
measured up with competence?

273
00:15:39.080 --> 00:15:41.350
Are things moving on target?

274
00:15:41.350 --> 00:15:45.420
And how do we move people around
the team to get even better outputs,

275
00:15:45.420 --> 00:15:46.350
better performance?

276
00:15:48.100 --> 00:15:52.325
And the last but not least on this one is
if you're gonna keep the team moving you

277

gotta constantly give them feedback,
coaching, training,

278
00:15:56.240 --> 00:16:00.600

better, more component, highly effective,

279
00:16:00.600 --> 00:16:05.420
highly efficient and doing high
optimization on the team themselves by

The training that's vital,

using those tools to improve the process,
streamline it and

more highly optimized.

292

>> Fantastic, we're getting kind of close

all motivation is motive for action,

it's unique.

you need to sit down and

Why would they buy, and figure out

the legacy they wanna leave

with being excellent on the team,

And then the big thing on optimization

>> I love that idea on motivation too.

Go back the day you hire someone and

It really makes communication

You also have to realize that
when you've got a virtual team
